CommentsTitle: 5 hours or so of use and left analog stick is toast. Pathetic.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 6, 2019
CommentsContent:
UPDATE 3/15/19: I took a hiatus from gaming since November. Literally used this for maybe 5 or so hours. The left analog stick broke. It doesn't click down. Really disappointed. Thankfully I'm like a week away from my warranty. So I have to send it back. Now I'm going to have to use my original Elite controller for the time being that is over 4 years old! It's pathetic that my elite one controller still works and this one breaks.

Original review: I have been using the first elite controller for nearly the last 4 years. It still works, but it's not without it's issues about quality.

This series 2 controller has some similarities with the first edition. But there are differences as well.

1. Internal battery and case charging

Microsoft was late to the party with putting a internal rechargeable battery in a controller. And it should be a standard across all of their controllers. But it's better than using the play and charge kit. Supposedly the battery can last up to 40 hours according to microsoft.

You can also use the case as a charging dock. But you have the option to charge via the controller as well.

2. Quality and feel

The feel of the controller is better than the first. Textures grips on the triggers and where you hold it feels more comfortable for a better gaming experience. Especially when you have longer sessions.

3. Peripherals

This controller comes with the following

1. 3 sets of analog sticks
2. 2 D pads.
3. 2 sets of paddles
4. Charging case
5. Braided USB charging cable (USB C)

This controller is very flexible. The parts are very easy to swap. I would reccomend experiencing with what configuration works best for you.

4. Price point

The price is a little steep. And it's $30 more than the series one when that came out. Unfortunately I have to dock a star off for that. While there are improvements, that should be expected more than 4 years later. And you shouldn't have to pay that premium for improvements 4 years later.

More importantly, While the improvements are nice over the first edition, I don't know if it's worth it when you can find the first one at solid prices these days.

5. Connectivity and functionality

If you are a PC gamer and have a bluetooth card, say goodbye to using a wire or having to buy that Xbox USB wireless adapter that sticks out of the USB port. This controller has internal bluetooth.

You can also switch different game controller settings on the fly. Up to 3 to be exact. You can have different pre sets for multiple games. The lights on the front will indicate which one you are currently on.

Case in point, Overall solid controller. Offers incremental improvements, but nothing too groundbreaking. 4 out of 5.

CommentsTitle: Nothing else to blame all my mistakes on now
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 5, 2019
CommentsContent: This is my first premium quality gaming controller that I've ever bought so I can't compare it to the Xbox elite series 1 or Scuff controllers.  The major advantage of these controllers for me is that I don't have to take my right thumb off of the joystick (which is used for aiming in most games) to press any of the other buttons.  This comes into play if you need to jump and aim or crouch and aim at the same time.  It sounds silly but those few milliseconds can make a difference if you're big on FPS games. I've been wanting to buy one for a while but read all about quality control issues with the elite series 1, so I figured I'd wait on this version and hope they were fixed.  So far I've been extremely impressed with just about every aspect of this controller.Pros:-Extremely simple and easy to set up button mapping.  It allows for you to assign any button to the four paddles on the back of the controller-Ergonomics: Feel is just like a regular xbox controller except that it generally feels more substantial and there are 4 paddles on the back.  They are positioned so that they are easy to press-Customization: It comes with a bunch of  different thumbsticks you can put on so you can decide what works best for you.  I like that you can adjust the tension of the thumbsticks.  I did what another reviewer recommended and increased tension then jacked up the sensitivity on my game.  This allows me to still move precisely when I need to but also look around much more quickly if I want.-Hair triggers: The triggers have customizable stops put in so you can designate both the left and right triggers as a long pull, medium pull or short pull (hair trigger).  For the hair trigger I only have to pull it very slightly to shoot which helps speed up my reaction time a bit-Battery: I've only played about 20 hours so far but the battery was still at above 50%.  Easily chargeable with your xboxCons:-Can't set up hotkeys (i.e. can't make a single press of a paddle be a double click of a different button)-Heavy, it is much heavier than a regular xbox controller due in part to the internal battery.  It doesn't both me but if that is important to you then this might not be the controller for you-Internal battery: This is a pro and con.  The battery life has been great so far but it will inevitably diminish and can't be replaced.This is where I am at after about 20 hours of playing with this thing.  I'll update a few months down the road or sooner if any issues arise

CommentsTitle: Awesome until something breaks a couple of months in.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 26, 2020
CommentsContent: Let me preface this by saying that I had the Xbox Elite Series 1 controller. It was my favorite gaming controller I had ever used for about 2 years, until the day the piece of plastic that anchors the left bumper to the central hub of the controller broke. After doing some research online, it seems that was a common issue for people. Rather than buy a replacement or try to repair it myself, I went back to my standard controller, as rumors of the Elite Series 2 had started floating around, so I figured I'd grab one when they came out.I finally got myself the Elite Series 2 two months ago (end of May). I love this controller, much like I loved the Series 1. I wanted it to last. But in the last week, both of the slides for the trigger locks have broken. More specifically, the "nub"/"tab" (not sure what to call it) that you use to slide up and down to the different lock levels, has snapped on both sides. I've included pictures here, though it's a little difficult to capture (and my camera was finicky with focusing in on them). There is still about half of the "nub"/"tab" left on either side - enough that if I use my finger nail I can catch it and slide it still (we'll see if the rest eventually breaks off?). Occasionally during play my fingers will brush by them now and feel the sharp edge where they snapped, or the sharp point at the end (previously rounded off).Let me say that I rarely used the trigger locks on the Series 1, and with the Series 2 I had move the right trigger lock to the lowest level early on and left it there, and not touched either lock since (i.e. never used the left trigger lock). This would be an issue for anyone I'd think, especially if you used the trigger locks or adjusted their levels frequently. However, it's especially baffling to me because I basically never touch them. My fingers don't rest on them during normal play. I am the only person in the house who uses/touches the controller. I'm very careful/gentle with it, I don't feel that I particularly put a lot of wear and tear on my accessories. I still have my Xbox One Day One edition controller that is in great condition. Last night after finishing up a play session, I unplugged my headset and went to charge the controller for the night, and as I leaned in toward the charger I heard a piece clatter to the table - the left trigger lock nub (the right one broke off in similar fashion about a week ago). I hadn't used or touched the trigger locks all night, and in fact had never used the left one.Admittedly this doesn't prevent me from using the controller, because as I've laid out I almost never adjust the trigger locks, and there is still a shard of the tab left that allows me to move them if I need to. Still. Microsoft is charging nearly $200 for this controller. It's supposed to be made out of premium parts/materials. It comes with a very limited warranty (I believe 3 months?). Going through their support only allows you to chat with a bot if you choose accessory support, and your only option is to send the controller off to a depot for repair. This review isn't specifically about Microsoft's warranty coverage or support options, but I feel like people should be aware of the full picture if these controllers are going to start falling apart in under two months, when gently used. I haven't knocked it all the way to 1 star because prior to the trigger locks breaking, I loved the controller. It feels premium. It's comfortable, it's weighty in a good way, the carrying case with built in charging dock is awesome, there are plenty of swappable accessory options, etc. But it's hard to recommend when you may not have long to enjoy all of the good bits before it falls apart.

CommentsTitle: Unhappy after years of waiting.. I am sad to say.. Grips like wet bars of soap
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 9, 2019
CommentsContent: UPDATED: 1/2/2020So trying to keep this as short as possible, I have owned 4 Original Elite Controllers - 2 of them replaced under warranty - So lets call that 6 Original Elite controllers. 2 of them I had to scrap for parts as they were out of warranty and become part of my parts supply to keep the others going. Other than the know issues I still liked those controllers.Now lets move on to the Elite 2 - I have now owned 2 of them about to be 3 as I have seen the following:First Purchased Elite 2 - Buttons sticking - A and sometimes B - But worse are the BT disconnects that seem to happen when the unit is plugged in and charging. (Clearly an issue as there is no removable battery). Note: I hate the grip material its way too slippery when compared to the original elite. I wish I could fix that in some way. It does not look like it will support aftermarket grips but maybe that would solve it. At least for me my hands physically hurt after playing for a few hours due to needing to grip the controller way harder than I had been used too. So that is a strange side effect I have found.**Two side notes, I think shipping it with vibration on for a controller that has no removable battery might be taxing the reported play hours per charge, also somewhere needs to be talked about if you use a chatpad and how might power that also can draw**So in trying to return the first elite to amazon they sent me a new unit for the swap - This unit at first would not pair with the console. I have seen these issues before on controllers in general, but got that working and it needed the normal update to firmware. This was done and no issues. Re-booted everything and all was working. Went to install my chatpad and nothing, it will not show up on the accessories app, it will not light up, it does nothing. Re-attached it to my other elite 2 before I ship it back for credit and it works fine?So I guess I am very concerned at the reliability of these quite expensive controllers. I have heard rumor that MS is working on this, possibly a software update etc. It is very strange how it reacts when attached to power for charging, and the buttons sticking is clearly a not great issue. I have heard rumors about stick drift issues persisting but I have not seen those personally.I guess I am checking to see how wide spread this might be and also to make sure that what I am experiencing is possibly Alpha Ring related for the software or possibly Firmware issues, as clearly the ring does not effect the buttons sticking etc I assume that is simply a hardware issue.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I have been looking forward to this controller since the 6 I have bought in the last few years all have failed in different ways. Grips falling off. Control stick drift and upper button failures due to non robust design.So far in using this controller I have found a couple undesirable issues and some nice redesigned items but right now the undesirable ones are bad enough to make the use experience less than fantastic.#1 is the new grip material is in one word slippery as ice and is actually so slippery that it is causing my hands to go numb as you need to hold onto the controller much harder due to the slippery grips. I put aftermarket grips on my original elites and they worked and felt great.#2 is the upper vibration motors are loud to the point of annoying and honestly just do not give the high quality feel I would expect for the very expensive price of this controller. I have just turned them off but the lower motors seems to sound and feel better much like the older version.I have not had it long enough to determine if the integrated battery is going to hold up or if the other redesigned items last for any long term but as a user that has been through many controllers and rebuilt several elite controllers I can only hope those items are actually fixed. But time will tell.

The New design to the grips do feel good tho.First thing about this controller I noticed is that it is slightly smaller than the version 1 (this could be something microsoft already mentioned when they announced the version 2 im not sure). Since it slightly smaller it also has a little less weight but it still has that weightiness that the version 1 has just very slightly less.The back paddle are also smaller and do not extend as much as the v1 paddle, which I think is ultimately a good thing but it will take maybe 30mins/hour to get use to the smaller paddles if you are use to the v1 paddles. The bumpers and triggers are also smaller but it still feels normal.Also the thumbsticks of the v1 controller are NOT compatiable with the v2 controller. And that is because the v2  has the new tension adjusting mechanic in the stick, so the thumbsticks themselves have new designs. As for the thumbstick that come with the controller: 2 short concave stick (smooth on the top surface but having a textured mesh-like on the sides like the typical v1 sticks), 1 short convex/dome stick with a textured patterned, 2 short wide surface concave sticks, 1 long concave stick (essentially the same as the v1 long concave stick). Im currently using the 2 short wide surface stick as I like the extra surface area of the sticks.It comes with long USB-C charging cable too and has a slot to insert the USB-C cord into to charge the controller on a charging dock that is inside case but of course you can just connect the USB cord directly to the controller to charge and play at the same time which is probably the way most of us will charge the controller but still a nice feature nonetheless.Only con I would have is my X button feels a bit stickier/stiffer than the A,B,Y buttons but im hoping that goes away as press the X more and more.I will say this controller is overall better than the v1 from design to feel to look but If you have a v1 elite already and are not suffering from the grips, stick drift. or broken button issues then you probably dont need to upgrade unless the tension stick adjusting and more button config profile, other things the v1 dont have are very important to you. Unfortunately only time will tell if the grips/drift issues have been solved.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 6, 2020
CommentsContent:
Do not buy this controller without a thorough understanding of the questionable durability of this product.

Elite Controller Series 1 has several very well documented design flaws. Simply search Amazon for Elite Controller Replacement, and you will find a whole cottage industry of replacement bumpers to address the most common flaw. Replacements for rubber grips falling off, replacement analog sticks for stick drift are other well documented but less frequent problems, that have replacement parts that can be purchased third party.

The problems with series 1 were not related to misuse.

Eventually, in response to widespread community complaint, Microsoft opened up their replacement policy. Rightfully so. The controller durability required it.

Therefore, it was with great fanfare that series 2 was released, with reported attention to each of these systemic issues.

The update was met with near universal praise. The early going was fantastic.

Unfortunately, the cat is now out of the bag. Worldwide the controller is less than 1 year old, being only released last October. And now the plethora of durability issues are again becoming evident.

The most frequently documented is "bumper double clicking" and "A button (or face button) sticking." Less frequent are complaints again reporting stick drift, and problems with bluetooth connectivity.

Unfortunately, I have not been spared these concerns. Several weeks ago, I began to experience the right bumper double clicking. Within several days, the problem progressed to involve the left bumper. Within a week, the right bumper would not register anymore.

I do not misuse my equipment, and the total hours of use low.

An internet search for Elite 2 problems will quickly identify that these shortcomings are once again systemic, and the number of persons affecting is growing on a daily basis.

A formal press release was published by Microsoft in November confirming hardware problems affecting gamers. There has been no formal follow up since that admission.

Once you experience these durability issues, which unfortunately I expect you will, you will find yourself seeking recourse.

When you follow the standard microsoft/xbox online support mechanisms, you will find that, unless the controller is within 90 days of purchase, your efforts will be fruitless. At the end of the process, you will receive an email that simply states the product is out of the replacement window. No other recourse will be offered.

90 days for a $180 device? This is not acceptable you will think.

Flabbergasted, you will be compelled to pursue the issue further. However, you will find thereafter, that it is not possible to speak to a live representative from microsoft about this problem. It is not possible. You will reach a dead end anyway you turn.

Eventually, if you continue to be frustrated enough at the perceived injustice to continue, you might find that, to connect to a live person, you have to pretend you have a different problem. If you pretend for example, that you would like to end your subscription to xbox live, you will then receive a call back from a live person. That person will be of no help, because they are on the software side, and your problem is hardware related. They state however, that they will transfer you to the hardware side. The connection may or may not go through. However, if you are persistent enough going through this side channel, you may eventually be connected to hardware support.

Support will state that they are aware of the problem, and "a ticket has been sent to the back end team."

What does that mean? you will ask. The response is repeated by the support team "a ticket has been sent to the back end team."

Doesn't this solve your concern? Is this response not self explanatory? Are you not satisfied?

Of course not. There is no time table provided. There is no mechanism for follow-up provided. No fix provided. No assurance that anything will happen at all. Meanwhile, you will find yourself with a $180 paper weight.

To be clear, this controller was 5/5 out of the box. Having owned multiple series 1, I preordered series 2 with tremendous excitement, and my early use was fantastic.

But this durability, or lack thereof, is unacceptable. The series 1, despite the numerous short comings, had community fixes for just about every concern. Users like myself learned the repair process, and kept their devices working.

There is no known fix for series 2. We are 100% dependent on Microsoft being forthright and honest, and taking care of their customers. That is not going well.

$180 for 6 months of use is unacceptable.

This controller gets 1/5 stars. Buyer beware.

(I will update this review if Microsoft responds to their community and corrects these systemic issues)

CommentsTitle: Buy with a means to extend your warranty or don't bother
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 27, 2020
CommentsContent: I've been a fairly avid gamer most of my life, and made the transition to using the Xbox at age 13. Until turning 23, I have only used stock controllers and relatively cheaper variants due to being young. At this point in my life, I can comfortably afford to spend more money on more premium products for that enhanced quality. Three and a half months ago, I made this decision for my console gaming experience when I bought this controller. My qualms are not so much with the controller's amenities but rather the longetivity.The ergonomics of the controller itself are great. It has a textured grip to improve handling of the controller, interchangeable joysticks and D-pads, paddles to increase variability to your gaming, adjustments to trigger pull for the FPS junkies out there, and a plethora of options for customizing what buttons do in the Accessories App. You can even use one button like a SHIFT key on your keyboard, allowing for even more options. I thoroughly enjoy using this controller as I learned to use the paddles. The paddles by default replace the "A,", "B,", "X," and "Y" buttons. This addition allows you to play games without having to move your thumbs with the exception of the D-pad, Start/Select buttons, and Xbox button. For someone really into FPS, this increases your efficiency by a notable amount once it is learned. I had a fantastic time using this controller when I gamed in my free time, until the drift came.My controller's left joystick has drift on its Y-Axis. What a controller should do once you release the joystick is return to the center. This keeps your character from moving when you do not intend for them to do so. What my controller does is keep the joystick tilted ever so slightly up or down, keeping my character moving in that direction when gaming and making it a hell of a challenge to select anything with an in-game cursor. I will use Apex Legends as an example. I jump onto a narrow ledge to make use of its elevation and I have a sniper with a scope. While aimed in, I make a slight movement up to see just a bit better. Next thing I know, I am falling off of that ledge to likely 50m below, where there were some enemies sneaking by and now I am dead. That slight movement of my character without my intent will cause issues like that to happen on a constant. The problem is even worse when I need to ping to my team for ammo, a certain attachment, or even to drop an item in my inventory. When accessing your inventory in Apex, you use a circular in-game cursor and move it with your joystick to individual items. Imagine how hard that becomes when my cursor keeps going up/down unless I take extra time to steady the stick to the center. That seemingly small problem impairs gameplay to the point I almost don't even use the controller and use a stock controller instead.I had actually never had joystick drift until getting an Elite Controller. Due to various reasons, I have been very busy these past few months, making me forgetful or at times unable to contact Microsoft, I got to contacting them this week for help as I did not want to void any warranty trying to fix a nearly $200 controller on my own. However, in a timely manner, I get a response telling me I can't be helped as I am past my warranty. I bought this controller on the 9th of February and got this response today, on the 27th of May. Not even 4 months past the purchase of this item, Microsoft will refuse to provide any help. Now I am hoping I can get some results from AMEX as I bought this controller with that card for an extended coverage of the item. If you buy this, be extremely careful with it, try to clean it, and do what you can to prevent development of a problem down the line as Microsoft will only stand by a nearly $200 controller for 90 days.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 17, 2020
CommentsContent: I've had two of these controllers. I've treated them with the upmost respect and security, making sure to never bang them on anything. I was incredibly gentle with them, and yet both of my controllers have broken within a single month.The main issue that this controller has is the same issue that normal Xbox One X controllers have. It is very embarrassing how Microsoft continues to attempt to milk their loyal gaming community by dishing out cheap, poorly made products.While the controller worked, it was amazing. CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 6, 2019
CommentsContent: Good controller.  I’ve had two of the first generation Elites.  The bumper trigger broke on the first one (lasted a bit more than two years) and the rubber grip pads eventually fell off.  Bought a second one (used) and got 6 months before the rubber grip pads started falling off.  (Not complaining, but these earlier versions definitely had some issues.)This one is the second generation and I like it.  The grips feel different - more secure and hopefully less likely to come loose.The internal rechargeable battery is cool.  It “clicks” magnetically with the charger and I really like that.The bumper triggers have three settings for depth of trigger pull - as opposed to two on the older version.  I like that too and set it into the middle.  Deep enough I feel it, but not so deep it causes problems in quick reactions.The metal button flippers on the bottom feel tighter - much better than the ones on the earlier version.  The old ones would sometimes work themselves loose during heated PvP for me.  These ones on the new controller just feel more “snug.”All in all, I can tell engineers paid attention and worked through a lot of old issues.  Definitely a good purchase for me.  (As a 40-something professional who plays Overwatch on the weekends, I need all the help I can get.)

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 2, 2019
CommentsContent: I went through two of the original Elite controllers and both of them eventually had grips that fell apart and even worse deadzone issues and drift. I really love the way the elite feels so I kept going back to it and I'm at the point now where I rely on the extra paddles so moving back to a regular controller is very difficult for me. I was hopeful that the v2 would be an improvement and so far it definitely has been almost everywhere. The charge works great and lasts a very long time. The paddles have been shortened and feel way better which is weird because I didn't think that was something that needed to be improved. The grip is worse but feels more durable so I can live with that. I love the fact I can store an additional profile and a default setting. I also like the tension you can put on the sticks. I use the default tension, but it's great that is an option. Overall this feels like a really solid improvement. I've used it for a month now without any issues. In my mind they should get a minimum of 2 years out of heavy play, and v1 only lasted me about 9 months each time (which is terrible), so we'll have to wait and see how it holds up.

CommentsTitle: Best controller I've used... until stick drift
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2021
CommentsContent: 5 stars for the controller itself: it feels great and I like how the paddles feel better than the comparable Scuf controller. While the new Series X controllers have imported some of the improvements (texture on the grips and on the triggers), the elite has a satisfying heft to it. I feel like you could defend yourself from a home invasion wielding one of these, and if anyone discovers how much you have spent on just a controller they may also think you have priceless jewelry or artwork waiting to be plundered so perhaps that's a real risk. Also: paddles are great for some games.Now to take away 3 stars: I only managed to get through one game before the controller began failing. For the record, the full game was Jedi: Fallen Order, not an experience that seemed inordinately demanding on the left controller. And I will say I very much enjoyed remapping the force push and pull to the paddles.Alas, I then started playing Dark Souls 3. About half way through my character began spontaneously walking forwards at inopportune moments. Yes, controller drift (on the left stick) had struck. This got progressively more severe until the controller was unusable. In case you're wondering, at no point had I thrown the controller around in the midst of rage quitting out of a troublesome boss: under those circumstances I just summon help, like the massive scrub I am. Yes, I pressed up on the controller a lot, but that's *a lot* of games that make you do that.This sadly doesn't seem to be an isolated problem. I find it odd that this should be happening to so many people seeing Microsoft have ample experience producing perfectly serviceable and (in my experience) robust normal XBox controllers. It's also really expensive compared to those controllers. I want to say "you get what you pay for", but obviously you don't. The Scuf controller I bought to replace this, while not feeling quite as fancy, has also held up much better.The only reason this review isn't one star is because if it fails as quickly for you as it did for me, it should still be covered by some sort of warranty so at least you might not be completely out of luck. In general, like an OLED TV and the fear of burn-in, this seems like one of those rare times you actually do want to take advantage of an extended warranty if it's available to you, for the peace of mind. If you are super price-sensitive you probably aren't considering this controller anyway, so consider the added expense as just the cost of doing business for that sweet paddle action.So despite my paltry two star review, I would actually consider buying this again with a suitable extended warranty. Am I an idiot? Don't answer that.

CommentsTitle: Bluetooth randomly fails and causes game to stutter
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2020
CommentsContent: Random connection drops and sync issues when using bluetooth.  Disconnects happen randomly - mid game the controller looses sync with the PC host and the light blinks.  At the same time the Bluetooth stack on Windows 10 seems to cause your game to pause/stutter/lock, and if you're lucky it will restore itself automatically.  If you're not lucky you completely lose Bluetooth and have to hit the Xbox button to re-sync bluetooth.If you're using it wired, works great.  Why the $40 xbox controllers work perfectly with Bluetooth but the $200 Elite don't is a mystery that only Microsoft knows the answer to.

CommentsTitle: Really not worth the money for what you get

CommentsContent: I thought that paying $170 for a controller would give me a quality product, unfortunately this controller just like it's previous counterparts have an inherit issue, that would be the thumb sticks. From the basic controller to this one it's only a matter of time of when they will start to drift without being touched. The warranty on this unit expired in May of this year and the drift started in June. Best part is Microsoft will be more than happy to replace the unit for only $99 plus tax. So in less then 5 months I have paid over $270 for an "Elite" controller. Honestly the price does not at all justify the few frills of programmable paddles and adjustable triggers and sticks. Not for the durability of the product. Also I'm not a young kid, I'm in my 50's and I did not abuse the controller at all. CommentsTitle: Known Issue: Right Bumper Double Click

CommentsContent: I noticed the issue a few months into use - light use ( I am 27 Y/O and take care of my devices). Recently I noticed pressing the right bumper every 3-4 clicks it registered twice. CommentsTitle: If you don't have 1, wait until V3 or a refresh of this model.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 11, 2019
CommentsContent: My A, B, X, Y were sticky, mostly from the sides & I disliked the noise it made. I also recommend cleaning your controllers buttons with green cleaner from Trader Joes or something similar, it'll help a bit, don't spray directly on it though.The controller doesn't reconnect to bluetooth after plugging it into pc, then unplugging it. I bought two Elites, this is my third, technically my 1st Elite series 2, I will not be buying a 2nd Elite after this because we beta tested the first model, this was their 1 shot, i put a lot of effort into what i wanted to see changed in the 1st model, they definlity heard us as gamers, i feel like they did a good job! CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 9, 2019
CommentsContent: So, first thing I have to say is for the love of dog, wash/cleanyour hands before using this controller. The matte finish will grab onto the oils in your fingers/hands and will leave the controller with obvious smudges and smears. They should have included a microfiber cloth in the box.Ok now that that is out of the way. My initial impressions.1. This thing is a BEAST! In its mass amount of features and functions yes, but even more so in its sheer weight!  This thing arrive in an amazon box not much bigger than the box for the controller itself, and when I picked it up I though they had sent me some kind of small anvil instead.2. Initial impressions of this one in terms of build quality are positive. I will update this section in a month or two. One of my favorite new features for this addition is the combination carrying/charging case. It’s honestly too good to be true, especially after the experience I had with V1.If you have any questions about the controller, or about other comparisons to the original elite, leave a comment and I will get back to you

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 22, 2021
CommentsContent: This is my third Elite controller the first two were the original ones where the grips fall off after 6 month but at least the buttons work and dont have major drift issues with the sticks,this new one "series 2" are absolute trash day one the A and X buttons had to be pressed extremely hard to make work and even then only worked about 70% of the time otherwise worked ok so i kept it thinking the A and X might just need to break in some,,well  they did not break in and now actually click twice most times they actually do work and now both sticks drift horribly both in a downwards direction and with microsoft not allowing you to adjust the dead zone anymore this controller is ready for the dumpster after maybe 40 hours tops of use,i have had $20 controllers from no name brands that have worked better,as an added bonus microsoft gives you the shortest warranty you could imagine with the things,if you want one of these buy it from bestbuy and get their warranty with it so you can keep exchanging it every few months when it breaks. dont let the fanboy reviews fool you these are trash and must have 0 quality control checks.

CommentsTitle: The Most Premium Controller I have Ever Used
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 15, 2020
CommentsContent: With normal controllers, I have to add adhesive grips, custom thumbstick caps, and rechargeable battery packs...Not with the Xbox Elite Series 2...I was able to select my prefered Thumbsticks, Back Padels, and customize my own profile, pretty much out of the box and all Windows 10 Downloads were free as well as under 10mb downloads. When all connectors needed to utilize the charger dock are all included and I need no additional purchases to obtain additional features it's made for good user experiences. Thankfully the entire kit comes in a premium zipper-enclosed carrying case (better than a bag), with specialized sockets for each component, so it's easy to stay organized (even when on-the-go)...Fully justified in rating 5 stars.When playing games, it works pretty much the same as a normal Xbox One controller, but feels so much better...kind of like sitting in a much nicer chair or looking a sharper and cleaner display. It can't offer a competitive advantage, but it will provide a lot more comfort. so the final rating is 5 stars

CommentsTitle: Built by slave labor monkeys who are managed by rocks.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 23, 2019
CommentsContent: First one- Really bad buttons, stick drift, crunchy dpad. Built by slave labor monkeys being managed by rocks.Second one- no more crunchy dpad, didn't notice stick drift. 'A' button only works with a specific press and feels flat. Paddle button on underside very inaccurate, sloppy and most of the time did not register. underside paddles fall out easily.Stick movement feels better on the regular controllers.Great controller but obviously it's being built in an impressively CHEAP way.Still being built by slave labor monkeys managed by rocks.Going for #3, it costs me nothing to keep sending this junk back. Someday I might have a good one.

CommentsTitle: BREAKS VERY QUICKLY UNDER LIGHT USE. DO NOT BUY.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 9, 2020
CommentsContent: I hope people will see this review, this is my first one and I don't know how this works.DON'T BUY THISI have owned plenty of Xbox 360 and Xbox 1 controllers and I have only had ONE break. It was a 360 controller that saw 3 years of constant use.(totally understandable why it wore down.)Now I work full time I don't play videogames much anymore, but I thought why not buy a fancy controller? It's compatable for the next Xbox and it's USBC. sounds great...Less than 6 months of light use, the controller is already broken.The left bumper will not register or it will double click. The retention spring inside is still fully functional, no part physically broke. It just does not register.The left stick also drifts now unless you set the stick to the heaviest torque setting. That is easy to set, but it now limits how you use that stick.I can't express how frustrating it is to buy a controller THREE TIMES MORE EXPENSIVE than a standard controller, just to break when it has barely been used.It's advertised as high quality. It is not.EDIT: I took apart the controller after realizing I couldn't get a refund. And I found a fix for the bumper. The bumper has a small, frail piece of plastic buffering where the bumper strikes the actual button. I took that out and replaced it with a slightly thicker piece of plastic cut out from an ordinary water bottle. After a little fiddling it works perfectly. Now it works, however my controller is a little jacked up from prying it open.

CommentsTitle: Junk - they still can't make a reliable Elite controller
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2020
CommentsContent: The original Elite had well documented durability issues, which Microsoft promised they'd taken care of with the second revision. Which, I suppose, they did. Unfortunately, they managed to introduce some new ones. After 2 months of use, the A button on my controller became intermittent. Moving your thumb around on the button, while depressed, would cause input interruptions, and that's IF the button press registered in the first place. The A button also liked to stick, just a bit, during release. The B button was also exhibiting similar issues, though less frequently.But wait, there's more! Of the four rear paddles, one lost it's tactile 'click' after about a day, though in fairness, it always worked. That same paddle also had issues with retention; it would regularly pop away from the controller after being released.The controller has been returned for Amazon credit. I don't even want a replacement. This is the second generation Elite, for $180, NONE of these issues are acceptable. I've gone back to my Xbox One controller, which survived a Sekiro playthrough and still works great.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 23, 2020
CommentsContent: Controller in hands feels great, it’s a step over the former elite controller, but my unit came with multiple issues, a little drift front right stick mostly when tightening it, right trigger in hair mode had a clinching feedback, d-pad left missed some registration, I was like ok this thing is on beta stage, that wasn’t the worst, like many negative reviews pointing that my Y button only registers from a certain angle very annoying indeed I could bare all those minors issues but that made me lost momentum when switching weapons and I ended losing few gunfights because of it, the main reason you’re purchasing this controller it’s making the opposite, it wasn’t help me to win games the controller is unreliable, so I had to returned it and wait for those quality issues to be fixed, P.D: I like more the paddles in the first elite controller I guess that’s something I can fix myself xD

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 23, 2020
CommentsContent: I have been gaming for 30 years, I have countless controllers from all eras of gaming and have never once broken a controller. Had this controller for 6 months and now the RB button barely registers. I have to press very firmly for it to work. Absolutely embarrassing quality. Numerous complaints about the bumpers for this thing, and out of warranty as they only provide 90 days. $190 pile of garbage. It astounds me that a button can go bad on a controller that costs this much money.I even called Microsoft to see if they'd acknowledge the issue and they guy on the line said there is actually a class action lawsuit against this controller, but it's for stick drift not the LB/RB issues (even though those are prevalent too). Regardless, what was his solution? Pay MS $50 and they'll fix it. Yeah that's what I want to do, throw good money after bad. The controller has a design flaw at it's core, it'll just go bad again.I looked up self repair options as well, opened the controller myself to find that the LB and RB buttons have extremely cheaply made thin pieces of plastic that wear with use. I put a tiny piece of electrical tape on the top of the one by the RB to help, and it helped a little bit, but this thing still performs worse than a crappy PowerA controller I got for my Nintendo Switch when playing a game that requires a lot of RB inputs like Enter the Gungeon or Zen Pinball.Ultimately, I have to dedicate a back paddle to RB inputs, and thus also re-train my brain just to make it functional. Frankly I only do it as to not feel entirely cheated out of buying this thing when I could be using my PS4 controllers or 8-bitdo ones I have lying around. I am a stubborn one that's for sure.Don't waste your money, don't buy this.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 8, 2020
CommentsContent: Controller worked fine at first, no sticky buttons, rumble was responsive and crisp, and connected fine via bluetooth and dongle. Fast forward to the most recent firmware update, dongle (old version and new) as well as USB connection are borked and the controller is not detected via windows USB adapter or direct USB connection, and Xbox accessories confirms this. Connects fine to PC via bluetooth, but cannot be configured or customized that way. It also connects natively to Xbox One X and is detected and configurable. Microsoft fix your issue so that I dont have to travel back and forth between Xbox and PC to use the functionality that I paid an extra premium to have.This is now a bluetooth only controller for PC due to your most recent firmware.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 9, 2020
CommentsContent: Disappointed by this controller.I've been an original elite controller user since it was released.  I know people have had issues with it but i've had it for several years and its been great (and still is).  For me one of its big weaknesses was the paddles.  They were too easy to press and didn't feel comfortable.  I addressed it with an addon (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XCVSMWM/ref=ppx_od_dt_b_asin_title_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1).What attracted me to the elite 2 was1) ability to just place the controller onto the base and its always charged when you need it.2) updated paddle design3) additional profile available4) tension adjustable thumb sticksAll of those were nice features and in practice were well done.Design wise, what I found not so good about the elite 2 controller were the grips.  The ones on the original elite controller were much better for me.  The new ones felt less grippy.  Also, the bluetooth connectivity to my pc's onboard bluetooth was terrible (my other devices work fine).  I had to dig out my pc adapator for xbox controllers which worked fine.I could live with the items above. but what finally made me return the controller was the dpad and the a button.  For the dpad to register the right direction i would have to press it hard on the right top corner (using the plus or removing the plus and going directly against it).  The a button had to be pressed with force to get it register.  The click you get when you press the button sometimes was not enough.  I didn't bother getting a replacement after seeing so many people with issues similar to mine.  I'm hoping Microsoft corrects these issues in a revision and then Ill think about it again.

CommentsTitle: Day one PC user. Feels like quality to the touch, but the experience is lacking.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 27, 2020
CommentsContent: I've had my Xbox One S2 Elite since launch day. Here are some important things to know about it:1) A small number come with joystick drift out of the box. Your recourse is warranty replacement.2) A larger, but still small number come with sticky buttons out of the box. Same recourse.3) If you plan to use it on anything other than a console (i.e a PC) plan on using it wired. A very large percentage of them develop bluetooth connectivity issues eventually. Dropped sync and massive frame hitching when it happens. There are no firmware fixes, warranty is your only recourse.Yes, the feel of it in your hands is one of quality. It's heavy and the paddles / sticks / dpad are metal. The battery is internal but lasts long enough I haven't had it die on me. The trigger stops are amazing for FPS games or others that don't need 2 inches of analog control. But the warranty kills the entire experience.The above wouldn't be terrible if the warranty support wasn't utterly lacking. You get 90 days to find issues and report them to support for a replacement. There is no guarantee that what you receive as replacement will not have the exact same issues. If the case of the wireless issues, you'd better hope they show up before 90 days. I was not so lucky, so Microsoft will not replace mine under warranty. Instead you're directed to a statement that they 'acknowledge' the issues but actual support ends there and they tell you too bad, buy another.I'm a responsible adult. I take care of my possessions, and don't drop or throw my controllers. I should not have to buy an extended warranty on a $180 peripheral to ensure I get my money's worth. A peripheral with known issues like this should be taken off the market and the issues fixed rather than continue to be sold. Mine lasted 4 months before the bluetooth problems started and its almost unusable without being connected now. Don't get duped, avoid it unless you like to gamble.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I'm in the age group where Atari was the big hit in the 80's and video games began making there way into the hearts and minds of many kids around the world.  Since then, in my spare time I will go back to playing video games for a little while to take my mind off of things.  In recent years I have tried several controllers that I can use via Bluetooth or cable.  I have used a wireless controller for years, but this Elite Series 2... is just incredible.  The design and grip and feel of the controller is very nearly perfect.  I have never used a better controller, for anything.  The buttons on the back are an amazing idea and although I have yet to implement them into my gameplay, I will be doing so very soon.  The controller comes with a great charging case, and many replaceable parts.  The hair trigger adjustment on the back of the controller was a game changer for me, I love having the ability to adjust it when I need to.  I highly recommend this controller to any gamer that appreciates a well made controller.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 3, 2020
CommentsContent: Honestly so disappointed with this $180 controller. The last one had its issues, and I assumed Microsoft would pay attention when crafting this one, but I was wrong. I understand many people here have had no issues; I wanted to be one of them. Just felt I needed to add my misfortune for others to see.The Issues After <20 Hours:1. The B button majorly sticks - Used this button a lot playing Rocket League - If button is pressed directly down, it sticks a bit, and if pushed on an angle, it will stick until pushed down at the opposite angle. Definitely the biggest issue.2.  The A button registers MOST presses, but for $180, it should register all presses. If the button is pressed too lightly, or again, at an angle, the button push will not be registered by the controller.3.  The left thumb stick is already beginning to drift. At any given time, the thumb stick may decide to stick in a certain position, causing constant input. If one is playing a game that has sensitive deadzones, it is extremely noticeable.Things I Like:1.  The paddles on the back have been redesigned, and they are MUCH better than before. They have a better feeling when pressed, and they also fit my larger hands in a more ergonomic way.2.  Much better feel in the grips than the first iteration.3.  The three settings of hair trigger are very well implemented.4.  As before, the controller has a solid, weighted feel. It is very satisfying to hold.This controller would be my favorite controller of all time, if not for the defects. One star is justified as the $180 controller showed defects after under twenty hours of game play. Buy one at your own risk; you may get lucky as others have

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Yeah, it's comfortable, and the interchangeable sticks/D-pads are nice. I love the paddles too, BUT THE CONTROLLER HAS SERIOUS PROBLEMS. Just three months of light use (maybe 8 hours per week) and the controller is malfunctioning on a somewhat regular basis.  Roughly every other day I use this thing I find myself trying to wrangle the controls, until I decide to stop playing out of frustration. Every one of the joysticks, paddles, and buttons, stick (not physically on the controller, but but a small motion to the left with my joystick sends the avatar spinning in circles) or go dead for several minutes. It's unpredictable and EXTREMELY annoying. My last cheapa$$ controller developed stick drift after about 8 months, which sucked, but it's better than this. I'd rather buy a cheap one every year or so than invest in this garbage. Two stars only because it worked great and felt great for the first couple months. I'm basically out $180, so pissed.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 1, 2020
CommentsContent: This will be a quick review.I've logged over 1,000 hours on the original Elite 1 without any issues. Getting the Elite 2 seemed like a no-brainer. After about 20 hours playing Dishonored 2, Destiny 2 and Borderlands 3 on the Elite 2, I think I've found my new go-to Xbox controller. From a gaming perspective, with some minor complaint, this controller is nearly perfect.I do have three minor complaints.1) Microsoft includes only one tall thumbstick on the Elite 2. The original Elite 1 included two, albeit not as tall. I much prefer taller thumbsticks as I find it easier for precision aiming. What's worse, the neither the original nor third party thumbsticks from the Elite 1 fit on the Elite 2. A silly decision, as there's nothing about the design of the tension modifier on the Elite 2 that would mandate such a change. We all know why they pull that nonsense.2) The second minor issue is the decision to give the Home button zero travel distance. I've got several Xboxes, a multitude of controllers (all three of my kids each have their own customized controller) and the new "clickiness" of the Home button on the Elite 2 throws me for a loop every time I use it.3) I'm not onboard with the decision to internalize the battery. I already have a solution for charging my controllers. Now I need to find space in my already-cramped entertainment center to accommodate one more or starting charging the Elite 2 on the kitchen counter space reserved for tablet and phone charging.Overall, I'm exceedingly happy with the Elite 2, especially the adjustable thumbstick tension and the inclusion of the taller thumbstick. It's not perfect **for me** for the reasons listed above, but its still an improvement over the Elite 1.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 3, 2020
CommentsContent: I pre-ordered and received this controller back in November of 2019. I got it plugged it in, updated it from my console, and absolutely love it! I play competitively so I used it pretty frequently. I kept it clean and don't bang it around or mash buttons, so recently I noticed an issue with my right trigger feeling, "sticky" or tough to press down.. which was immediately noticeable, I figured it might have been because I got something stuck in it, but after thorough inspection and sitting there just pressing it, it seems it's a manufacturing issue, which is extremely disappointing; now currently a week after first noticing the issue, the (hair trigger) option doesn't register and the "stickyness" of the trigger is worse. I did a quick Google search and looked at recent reviews and noticed a lot of similar issues with sticky buttons.. I'm hoping to contact Microsoft/Amazon and see if I can get this replaced, because I'd hate to have to rebuy another expensive controller; for an almost $200 controller.. I didn't expect an issue like this, even so soon, especially since I take such good care of my electronics. I hope this issue gets resolved with later models. (Edit: apparently you don't get the warranty if you purchase it off here; at least that's what they told me. I bought a second one and had the same issues as the last.. broke the thing into tiny little pieces and threw it in the trash along with the other one. A sole waste of money, and a scam from Microsoft. I'm truly disappointed)

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 21, 2020
CommentsContent: Wow this controller was amazing for 2 weeks. Loved every single thing about it and read up on it before I bought it. I’m a big time gamer I got the router, the monitor, the one X so I figured one last upgrade and I’d have my perfect setup and then, the drift stick. I tried the accessory setting dead zone, and even had it at 79 79 on fortnite dead zone settings and both the look and move dead zone and still had unbearable drift stick. I have a warranty and I’m waiting for it to return to try it again and maybe someone else gets better luck but be aware, if you’re willing to spend $220-$250 on a controller, get the warranty. These controllers are known to get drift stick and don’t be like me and think you won’t get it bc I got it the 3rd week of having it brand new.

CommentsTitle: So much better than the standard XBox Controller!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2021
CommentsContent: Same shape and buttons as the standard XBox One controller, but:* Feels 3x heavier  I like it. Others do not.* Sticks have replaceable rubberized knobs with more or less friction  The most-sticky one felt best, but the one with the least friction is what I settled on for general comfort.* 4 paddles  These are extra inputs that may be attached underneath which can be mapped to any other button, as well as some additional functions of the platform, such as "Take Screenshot" or "Record what just happened".  One of the paddles can optionally work as a Shift key to change the behavior of any other button on the controller (not just the other 3 paddles).  One use of the paddles could be to move forward, while another could move backward. This saves the thumbs!Cons:(1) The problem with mapping paddles to LS is that they glitch and intermittently stop, then start again. You could be dead in that half a second delay.  This could be because of the way they are not solidly connected. Instead, the paddles insert into the bottom and attach magnetically. I've even had one fall out in-between games and only noticed at during the next game when I went to use it and ... nothing was there!  I am tempted to find a way to solder them in place to see if that's the reason for the glitch.(2) There are not enough functions for the paddles to map to. You cannot Sprint, for example, since I didn't find a way to map a paddle to LS-forward + LS-press.(3) There are not enough buttons!  This controller is expensive. I would expect a few additional levers and buttons to be able to map to special functions, which could be left unmapped for those who don't want or need them.

CommentsTitle: My opinion Microsoft doesn't care about you or quality on this controller
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 14, 2021
CommentsContent: We all want to love this controller. Unfortunately all of the quality is on the outside and even that is an illusion.Inside you have extremely cheap thumb-stick modules.... so cheap in-fact that Microsoft had a class action lawsuit. I have a post lawsuit controller that microsoft appears to have replaced that module with an equally terrible one.Microsoft support for issues on a 200 controller are laughable. At this price point microsoft should allow advanced replacements. (They dont according to their customer care). So your stuck shipping it back in your own box and waiting weeks for your replacement.I called microsoft asked for an advanced replacement was told they had submitted it for two weeks before finding out it wasn't and its not even a possibility. Microsoft lied to me. Then refuses to make anything right and asked me to ship it in standard and wait weeks.This is my second controller. My first had the same issues as everyone else.Dont buy this controller. Buy a high quality third partyBased on the quality of parts inside these controllers id guess Microsofts bill of materials gives them substantial markup on these controllers.Microsoft is literally tone deaf to its target audience. Gamers dont want to wait weeks for their controllers.In contrast if apple phone breaks apple has a new one to me in a day.Microsoft lied to me and their turn around times are poor.I want to love this controller. But microsoft only cares about profit. They dont care about quality. This controller is designed to appear to be high quality its internal parts are garbage

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 15, 2020
CommentsContent: I preordered this, after having a scuff for the last 2 years. I received it on 11/1/19. It took me about two weeks to get used to it compared to the scuff as the paddles where in different locations. I love it and would take it over a scuff any day of the week! I have had no issues with it disconnecting, like the scuff did. I love the ability to program the remote in the software on xbox and have 3-4 profiles. I also like that you can program any of the buttons or sticks to the paddles; a limitation on the scuff. The battery life is also incredible. I get well over 20 hours of gaming on a charge; my guess is that I am getting about 40 hours or more as I have charged it twice since getting it. I think the scuff has better grips but I have gotten used to the elites grips. I have noticed that most of the time I have to turn it on twice as the first time it flashes for a second and shuts off. I also can't change the brightness of the center logo button but it is dim so I am ok with that. The warranty is now 1 year instead of 90 days so that is also great. The controller feels solid and of high quality; I am very pleased. I would highly recommend this controller and would get it instead of a scuff as I was quite disappointed with my scuff and had to send it to scuff for repair 2-3 times which was a lot for occasional use.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 22, 2020
CommentsContent: After about one year, my controllers left bumper is non-functional. After contacting Microsoft, they offered no repair service and recommended a replacement. Ugg. I was fed up. There is no way I’m spending another $180 replacing a controller that fails in one year. It’s simply too expensive and not worth it. I did open it up in the hope that It was repairable by simply inserting a piece of plastic between the plunger and actuator. Unfortunately I found at the actuator (i.e. the button) was the problem and there’s no practical way to replace it. So that’s $180 down the toilet. The controller played great for about a year but that’s simply too much money to spend especially when the $60 controller controller Seems to last much longer! It just doesn’t make any sense. Why is the elite series controller so prone to reliability and longevity problems. Microsoft must do better than this.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 6, 2020
CommentsContent: I've gotten four of these controllers from Walmart and returned them all, and plan on returning this one from Amazon as well, because all of the A buttons are unresponsive if pressed at random angles, angles that you press during game play. This is incredibly annoying as a Rocket League player who has their boost bound to A, you jump to go for the ball, your boost doesn't work, you lose the game, simple as that.Microsoft obviously does not test these controllers, 5 different controllers, all with the same problem. They have no support page for their controllers on their support page (that I've found) and many more people have this issue, they've known about the issue since November but it hasn't been fixed, they either don't care or don't know how to fix the issue.If you're not constantly pressing your A button the controller is perfect, the weight makes you confident with it's build, it's black and dark gray across the entire controller which looks VERY nice, the sticks feel too stiff but grant surprisingly  good accuracy, the profiles are great for different types of games, the grips feel amazing as they go around both sides and not just the bottom, the paddles are the best on the market in terms of positioning, and the "wireless" charger in the case gives you a sense of technological advancement. The controller is superb in every way and is superior to Microsoft's other controllers, but I cannot get past the unresponsive A button which is much more persistent than I would've thought.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 6, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought this back in February.  When I first bought it, the A button was unresponsive and I sent it back to get a replacement. The replacement I recieved also has a slightly unresponsive A button, but it wasn't bad enough to return. Today, July 6th (only 5 months after purchasing) one of the trigger stop switches just broke off. We don't use that feature that often, so there shouldn't be much wear. I expected much better from an "elite" controller. We originally bought the first series as well, and a plastic internal component of the right trigger broke within a year (which after researching seems to be a common problem). The controller functionally has been great, its comfortable to use, and definitely enhances the player's experience, but it doesn't hold up over time which is unfortunate. I wouldn't recommend buying for the full price with how quickly these controllers tend to break.

CommentsTitle: Amazing product (if you get one that's made right)
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 26, 2019
CommentsContent: I love this controller. Feels amazing, extremely comfortable, the configuration and shift key concept opens up so many options, tensioners very useful.  That said , honestly I dont know what madness is driving me to give it a five star though. I guess I really wanted to like it ! The one I got shipped from amazon was defective like may of the 1 star reviews here (unresponsive A button and right stick click). Instead of returning I took to microsoft store and they swapped it out without much hassle( and didnt take much convincing to buy the 20 dollar 3 year extended warranty). Thr SECOND controller had no right stick issue but did have am unresponsive a button again(better than first but not perfect-so not acceptable). Then just exchanged a 3rd time. Now no defective buttons and I can enjoy the games... so far I love it no questions asked.  I sincerely hope Microsoft resolve whatever QA systemic nightmare lead to launching 180 dollar contoller that are literally supposed to be able to register a total of 6 buttons, 2 triggers, and 2 sticks... with defective buttons...(Does that read like a 1 star review to anyone)If the contoller wasnt so.. amazing ... I would've given up and 1 started it a long time ago. Hoping 3rd 1 sticks.

CommentsTitle: Still can't manually reassign the extra triggers to keys. Everything else - excellent.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 27, 2020
CommentsContent: I owned the Xbox One Elite's first generation (despite never owning an Xbox One) and used it as my primary controller for everything. I fell in love with the weight, grips, and beveled D-pad. Unfortunately, these have a routine and excessively common issue, and the shoulder bumpers broke about a week after it was out of warranty. This appears to happen to basically everybody eventually. I bought extremely inexpensive aftermarket bumpers, replaced them, and never had another problem with the thing despite near daily use for 4 years.Unfortunately, a couple months ago, it developed a dead zone in the stick. This is completely, absolutely reasonable with that amount of use over such a long time, so I looked into replacing it and found out about the Series 2. After getting one, I have no complaints whatsoever. The shoulder buttons are holding up for now (though a professional disassembly and review said they probably have the same problems as the last one) and everything else is either exactly the same or notably improved. The 3 stage triggers are particularly nice, the middle stage is just right for me, and wasn't an option on the old one.It's a bit heavy, but the inbuilt battery lasts far far longer than I would expect, and the charger is amazing. It's magnetic in a way that makes making sure it's set on the charger and connected brainless and super easy. I was hesitant about the switch from the old AAs (I used rechargeable) to the inbuilt battery but in the end, it's a major winner. Very happy.The only issue I would warn potential buyers about (besides the shoulder buttons, who knows if that problem continues in this one) is that you cannot remap the extra 4 triggers you can add to basic keys. If you google around you'll see a bunch of stuff saying you can remap it with some first party Xbox app for the computer, and that's true-ISH - you can remap it to other CONTROLLER BUTTONS. But you can't just map it to keys, it just doesn't support it at all. In the end, the solution for this one is the same as the last one, just by a ReWASD license. I typically hate licensed software and tried all of the open source alternatives but none of them really compare. Save yourself the hassle, spend the $6, and buy ReWASD if you need to remap those extra triggers. It's $6 on a $200 controller, anyway.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I liked the functionality and feel, however durability is extremely disappointing.  One of the paddles has stopped functioning after little use, and now the right bumper barely functions (I must press extremely hard for it to register).I have gamed for decades.  Xbox One controllers are the most unreliable devices I have ever used (I have controllers over 10 years old that still work).  The only conclusion I can come to is that they are designed to fail.A bit over days is about all you will get out of this expensive controller... just beyond the warranty.I've lost count how many controllers I have purchased for this console.I'm wondering if it is time to switch to a playstation...

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2020
CommentsContent: This controller is absolute garbage in one aspect: it’s not wireless. This is the whole entire point of spending $200.00 on a ‘state of the art’ gaming peripheral. Literally everything else is great- except that it doesn’t work, which means that the entire thing is as utterly useless as a fancy paperweight. I have used it on my $3000.00 Alienware and additionally have a $150.00 wireless mouse (ROG SPATHA) which has absolutely no issues playing games such as Dark Souls III and Code Vein. Meanwhile, even with the proper controller driver installed and the newest Windows OS active, I find the controller FREQUENTLY disconnecting from my computer. Sometimes it reconnects after actual minutes, other times I have restart the controller or re-introduce it to my computer by erasing it first. This is unacceptable and I will be returning it and purchasing something from a more reliable brand such as Logitech, Razer, or Corsair. Overall, if you like the look of the controller and fancy magnetic analog sticks, please buy it. But if you want a functional device which actually does what it’s fundamentally designed to do, buy anything else.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 14, 2019
CommentsContent: This controller is close to perfection. Microsoft had updated almost every aspect of this controller for the better. If you had a series one then this thing takes it to the next level.Unfortunately Microsoft still isn’t the best at making hardware. Long story short my A and Y buttons aren’t 100 % responsive. For something that costs $180 any flaw isn’t acceptable.Personally I’m returning my amazon unit and getting one from Microsoft so that if I get a good unit then I can add their 3 year extended warranty.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 22, 2020
CommentsContent: I had to exchange the first one I got because the BT was a disaster! The 2nd one connects ok. But not smoothly. BUT even though it connects, the latency is garbage. Definitely not useable for shooters. I ended up having to buy a separate wireless adapter to get this controller to work properly (Wirelessly). Having to buy this adapter is a spit in the face from MS. Considering how much this controller cost, they should have at least included one if not 10! I also should add that all the regular Xbox controllers that I've used in the last 5 years that have built-in Bluetooth have all be great, never had any issues connecting, with very low latency compared to this one. Very useable for shooters. If you don't NEED this controller and want to use BT, DON'T get this one.I got this controller because I seem to be heavy-handed (or rather, heavy-thumbed) with my controllers and pretty much have to buy one every 12 months or so. I'm hoping this one will last a little longer than the regular controllers. The control sticks on the underside are a bit too close together for me, and I had to remove the bigger set because I constantly hit the wrong stick. I'm also getting used to using them and often forget that they're there. Hopefully, I will get used to having them, they definitely are handy to have.

CommentsTitle: Faulty hardware, sticky buttons, stick drift - eventual degradation of quality/condition over time
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 15, 2020
CommentsContent: As stated, the buttons and such on the controller are sticky and often do not work unless you mash a bit to get them to fire - which is a bunch of crap for a “premium” controller. This is a bit hit or miss depending on the batch you get, and whether you get lucky so in terms of button quality - your experiences may vary with the controller out of the box. The only good news here from my experiences is the buttons do not get any worse.What does not vary, and what is completely unacceptable though - is the eventual and inevitable stick drift. This will get you, it’s only a matter of “when”. Stick drift on these controllers, is the continued registration of a tilt of the thumb sticks despite the user not (or no longer) applying any input to the stick. Very similar to the debacle of the Nintendo JoyCons (minus the free repairs Nintendo provided). This is most prominent in games with sensitive detection of movement, where your inputs will start to extend long after you release the stick. Sad news here is if you do not have stick drift, or it’s not so bad at first - it will be.My thumb sticks deteriorated over time, eventually beginning to drift so bad that tapping up would get stuck in the menus of the console’s home screen - a mere 6 months after purchase, meaning it’s drifting a LOT. This was not always the case and no significant event occurred that would have caused this to happen, besides the possible wear and tear from regular use. I am a disabled gamer, with frail hands and whom does not play a whole lot - so I do not provide a lot of persistent nor heavy pressure to buttons or sticks, so take this as a warning - this product, under even the weakest duress - will give out on you. You just wait - It’s well documented and trending in reviews. It’s a real problem.Spare yourself and do not buy these controllers until the Xbox team and hardware engineers put some pride and care into their products again. The first Elite Series controller was a keeper which I’ve since returned to, but the Series 2 is a lazy and reckless re-envisioning, that despite the big positives and upgrades to the original - is a complete disappointment and a overall faulty piece of tech with flaws and defects that no consumer should have to accept at this price point.

CommentsTitle: Awesome New Gen Controller - Total Rework!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 28, 2020
CommentsContent: Overall:  Great New Gen Controller!  Ignore the ignorant charging cradle, and enjoy the new feel and response!WARNING: For some bizarre reason, Amazon sticks a REFURB in your Basket!!!  HIGHLY advise to choose a NEW controller directly from MS!SHOCKINGLY GREAT!  Was really pleased with the solid feel, spring in the buttons, triple level settings for the triggers, better tab trigger placement, slightly smaller/better handing form factor, AND the new covering is Way better!  The new covering feels plush, but not slippery, and doesn't heat up.  I was expecting "just another elite controller", but this is truly an upgrade!  Better Shoulder attachments, which has historically been a weak point, so this one feels like it will last longer, finally fixed!Downside: battery is enclosed (but they did make it rechargeable!  Note: you need to charge before first use.), and the recharging cradle is awkward at best.  However, you can just plug a USB-C right into the back of the controller, and skip the lame cradle, or in-case charging (which should never be done anyway - never charge a battery inside a closed case due to heat).Note: I'll Update if things change.Note 2: Insure it if you can!UPDATE: the Stereo jack doesn't seem to work with my Mic!  Could be a config issue - using full headset for now... Will post an update.

CommentsTitle: Left stick broke in less than 8hrs of play time.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 12, 2019
CommentsContent: The initial impression is great. The initial perceived quality is impressive but the controller doesn’t hold up. The left stick no longer works after about 8hrs of play time. I’m going to replace and see if the next unit also fails.Update 11/22/2019: The replacement controller was defective with the sticky button issue right out of the box. CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 26, 2019
CommentsContent: While the sleekness is nice. It is smaller than it's the previous model which is bad for big handed folks like me. I wish it was bigger and thumb sticks were compatible with previous model.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 1, 2020
CommentsContent: Absolutely terrible, I’ve been gaming for 10+ years and never have a come across a “premium” gaming product that is so poorly manufactured in my life!
