CommentsTitle: Make sure to check the a b x y buttons
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Consistent with a few other reviews, I received a controller with terrible a b x y buttons. Rest of the controller worked as advertised. But for spending almost $200 for a controller, I expect no flaws. Given the amount of people complaining about the same thing, I don’t think this is a fluke. I think this is just a bad controller in general.

CommentsTitle: On my 2nd one already.  Power button issues, disconnected on its own & stick drift showed up too!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 12, 2020
CommentsContent: 1st one didn't last 30 days so I luckily got in on the return window.  Amazon didn't like it and sent an email saying so.  I hope the replacement holds up better.  The 1st one felt nice and worked as well as the version 1 Elite I've used since 2015, but went through 3 of them!  MS replaced the 1st one a year into use.  I treat them like babies btw.  The built in battery is annoying to me as I have my own drop in rechargeable, but if you don't its there already.  You have to use the built in charger though and it's in the case.  That's how I kept mine anyway, so no big deal, but it could be depending on your storage setup.  More software adjustments and settings but none I use.  One extra trigger length setting too.  Handy but not enough of a change to matter.  The extra rubber grip is nice and the paddle layout change is good too.  Although I didn't have an issue with the series 1 paddles.Overall a good upgrade if it holds up.  If not, 1 star all the way!  How can you pay almost $200 for a controller that doesn't last with adult low use and high quality care.  Stick drift has been reported by several reviewers and showed up quickly on my 1st one.  Light, but when you released the stick you would start to move or spin in game without touching the remote.  Even minor this is an annoyance and enough to request a replacement even if Amazon doesn't like it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 7, 2019
CommentsContent: Came with a rumble motor that makes a high pitch ringing noise. Can’t replace it without having to go through the hassle of buying another temporary controller.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 31, 2020
CommentsContent: Bought this controller. Played with it. Found out the Y button wasn't always responding. Updated it. Used the button testing app. Still. The Y button only worked when it felt like it. Just got a replacement, after returning the first one. And I have the exact same issue. In addition, the new controller also has wiggly sticks. Sooooo. I'm pretty peeved. I loved my series one though. Looks like this is a common problem also. I'll come back and update this if my next replacement is better... Otherwise. I recommend waiting on buying this thing

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I have two standard Xbox Elite controllers, one is very old and it still worked but was showing its age with mushy buttons, a little drift, rubber grip separated and of course bumpers that broke (I replaced them). But the controller performed well most of the time and I really liked the extra features (paddles and trigger adjustments). So I bought a second Elite once the first one got to loose. The second one also performed well and after 3 years is still working (again suffering a broken bumper). I replaced the bumper but it didn't work properly (had to push harder than the other bumper) so I purchased the newer Elite 2 controller. It is very similar to the original and I like it a lot. it has different grips that wrap around more (and so far have not separated) but they are slicker than the older version and can get slippery if your hands get sweaty. The paddles are again a great feature as is the trigger adjustments. The stick tension adjustment is a nice addition. The included battery charging puck is nice and heavy for stability and magnetic so it sticks to the controller when charging. Battery life is good and so far the buttons/paddles are working perfectly and still nice and tight.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Unfortunately I, like many others have a dead A button out of the box. Just received my controller yesterday, and started noticing it right away. Thought I’d give it a few hours of play to see if it would improve, but it’s actually gotten noticeably worse. Not to mention, my paddle which is default mapped to B is hit or miss. I feel the tactile click of the paddle but it only works 75% of the time. Unless the A face button is MASHED it hardly works at all.  Extremely disappointing considering this is a $180 piece of equipment. Not until I googled though did I notice how many others are suffering from this problem. At this point I can’t find much feedback from Microsoft regarding what should be considered a major problem.

CommentsTitle: Over rated, over priced. Still some pros.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 2, 2020
CommentsContent: Over rated, equally over priced. It feels great, looks great, plays great, but not compared to the cost. It is not worth the price. Besides that, the "metal" parts seem to rub off onto ones fingers, and the rubberized grips make ones hands overly sweaty. I do not normally have sweaty hands. Very noticeable after only a few minutes of game play after the first use. It's heavier than other controllers, actually giving it a nice feel, the triggers are very soft when pulling them all the way. Unless you have the hair trigger on, then they are very "clacky", for lack of a better word. (It's beyond me why they did not make the hair trigger settings as soft as the regular setting). After some serious gaming, I am noticing the thumb sticks, even at their highest tension, feel as though they are becoming very loose. If the price was more reasonable, I would suggest it for its Pros. Considering the Cons, it's not worth the price.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 20, 2020
CommentsContent: Update: 8/28/20. The 3rd replacement has developed an issue with the A button not registering at times.  Will return and buy something else.Some quick comparisons to the original Elite Series 1 Controller:1)Compared to the original Elite controller the grip on the series 2 is not as grippy.2) The weight distribution on the Series 2 controller feels more evenly distributed and therefore does not feel as heavy and clunky as the Series 13)The tension adjustments on the Series 2 takes a little to get used to.  But once you do, it's great for precision.4) The triggers on the series 2 just feel better and more responsive.5) Battery life on the series 2 is amazing.All in all the Series 2 is a great upgrade to the Series 1 except for the grip..  However, I can't seem to get a controller without button issues or stick drift. Microsoft needs to tighten up their quality control and figure out what is going on with all these faulty controllers. Because I have no idea how they let this many faulty controllers out into the wild.  Also please Microsoft extend the warranty for at least 6-12 months.90 days of warranty for an expensive piece of equipment does not show much faith in your product.8/11/20I am on my 3rd Xbox Elite series 2 controller with different Lot Numbers.  The first lot number I received was 2020 which had the infamous unresponsive A & Y buttons at times.  Then after that I received Lot number 2021 controller which had stick drift issues on the right stick.Now the 3rd controller that I have received is Lot number 2025 and I don't seem to have any issues at the moment(fingers crossed).  I will continue to update this review as time goes by and if any issues crop up.  I think I will have to move on to a different controller company if this controller has any issues.If you play Warzone please go into the setting and adjust your deadzone for the controller to around .06-.07 depending on your controllers deadzone.  For some reason Warzone seems to be super sensitive and needs the deadzone to be adjusted.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 23, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought this straight from Microsoft despite all the terrible reviews of sticking buttons and drifting sticks. CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 9, 2020
CommentsContent: So i do give Amazon 4 stars but to Microsoft 1 star, because the is a 180$ controller that should be near perfect, although it might just be my bad luck it shouldn’t happen to everyone, i am now receiving my third replacement for this controller because the first two were defective, same issue for both, on one the A button was not registering and would frequently stick, the second was the B button same issue, so hopefully third times the charm, if you order this elite series 2 controller just hope its perfect right out the box, Amazon took care of me and sent me replacements after talking to customer service.

CommentsContent: I just received this controller yesterday, 9/19/2020. The upper right paddle doesn't work right and the sticks drift. Just unbelievable! It's just like the poor quality of the Elite Series 1!The upper right paddle doesn't work right. I have to press the paddle in very hard to get it to register. CommentsTitle: 4 month warranty? They know this thing breaks.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 9, 2020
CommentsContent: Microsoft's warranty given with this controller is only 4 months. They do not offer you an additional warranty to purchase when you buy this. They KNOW when this will break down and support actually has the nerve to suggest "you're free to purchase a new one!" How helpful. I bought this in December 2019 as a much anticipated gift. It hasn't even been one year. It's cared for like a beloved grandmother by its owner. Now the right bumper is failing - half the presses don't register. We tried everything in the configuration menu to reset it, nothing. The button isn't easily removed or replaced, and its owner doesn't want to risk a DIY repair at home so we contacted support. Microsoft support literally told me they won't and can't help, that they aren't able to repair this controller when a button breaks, that warranty replacement was our only option and we were out of warranty. Then shuttled us off the phone and out of chat.This kind of product should be warrantied for a year; at this price point, I should AT LEAST have been offered a secondary warranty to purchase. I'm extremely disappointed with Microsoft; their hardware, their repair capabilities, and their customer service.This is why people buy Apple - at least they'll allow me to pay them to repair the darn thing if it breaks.

CommentsTitle: Don't waste your money on this eternal dumpster fire.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 3, 2020
CommentsContent: Let me count the ways Microsoft screwed this one up.-Abysmal quality control.--I've gone through 6 of these controllers and EVERY SINGLE ONE has had the same problems. Sticky face buttons, sticky triggers, and unresponsive A button.-Garbage warranty--Microsoft only offers a 90 day warranty... on a nearly $200 product. If you want the extended two year warranty, you need to PURCHASE IT FOR $20 from the Microsoft store.-Random disconnects--The controller has bluetooth! Hooray! Only problem is that it randomly disconnects mid boss fight and the only way to reconnect it is to hold down the power button for 10 seconds to hard shutoff, remove it from the paired devices list in your computer, then RE-PAIR IT with the computer. Rinse and repeat every 45 minutes to an hour of gameplay. OR buy their stupid adapter that you're not supposed to need. My $45 8bitdo controller has never had a single connection issue over BT, I can't imagine why this "Elite" controller can't get it right.Honestly, for $180+, this controller is a flaming garbage fire. It's so close to being good, but it's kneecapped by it's incredible failures at basic functionality that it makes it a non-starter. I'm blown away by this thing somehow having 4.5 stars in Amazon. This controller is the basis for an ongoing CLASS ACTION LAWSUIT over stick drift and quality issues.This controller is so notoriously bad that there's one of the largest reddit threads of all time (in r/xboxone) made up of fans who just wanted to get a working elite controller, most of which have bought and RMA'ed multiple (some, up to 12 units) elite controllers over the period of several months to years. I finally gave up after receiving my 6th one and realizing that they must all be defective, since every single unit I've received has the exact same core problem (the A button), with a surprise grab bag of other problems (sticky buttons, stick drift, leaking adhesive on the thumbsticks, etc).So, TL:DR-Don't waste the next 3 months of your life warranty swapping this melted turd over and over again hoping for a golden onion. It's not gonna happen.And don't trust these 5 star reviews.If you do decide you like pain, go ahead and drop your $200 and roll the dice, but the first thing you should do is plug it in to your PC, open the Xbox controller app software, and check each and every button many times. I guarantee you that A button has problems registering on light presses and on any angle other than directly on.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 20, 2020
CommentsContent: On the surface, the Elite Series 2 looks like a true enthusiast's controller. It has a very nice weight to it, the radial d-pad is great, the extra analog stick options are neat, and the paddles on the back promise a unique utility you've probably never used before. However, the cracks in this controller start to show almost immediately after seriously using it for the first time. Within 10 minutes of using my first and second controllers, I noticed the following problems:- Unresponsive face buttons. Just because you press a button far enough for the "bump" or "dip" to happen, the input may still not be read. For example, if I flick my thumb across a face button, like I want to input a short-hop jump in a platformer, there's a good chance I won't jump at all. For the A-button, I can replicate this almost every time if I try.- Aggressive snap-back on analog sticks. These sticks are heavy but they glide very smoothly. I really like the feel of them. But either they're too heavy or the spring in them is too strong, because if I flick my left stick all the way up and release, there's a >50% chance that it will snap back so quickly that it will pass through the neutral position and input down for a frame. This makes the analog sticks basically worthless for quick, aggressive movements, which can occur in almost any game.- Loose-feeling paddles. I feel like I can move the paddles in the back too easily. The magnet fixings for the paddles make it easy to remove and replace the paddles at your leisure, but this convenience comes at the cost of stability.I want to love and use this controller so much. I mean, I spent a bunch of money on it, surely I deserve to have a controller with reliable buttons and control sticks, at least, right? These issues shouldn't show up in any controller over $30, let alone over $100. These issues are widespread, too. Searching "Elite series 2 stick drift/unresponsive buttons" will show dozens of forum posts from users experiencing these problems. I often think one star is too strong a negative rating for most things, but these problems are supposed to be the first things to avoid when designing a controller. That these problems also showed up on two of my controllers in a row just shows the lack of quality assurance coming from Microsoft with these controllers, which just baffles me. Don't spend your money on this, you'll get a better experience out of an old Xbox 360 or PS4/5 controller.

CommentsTitle: Poor Build Quality (My 2nd Time Buying This Controller)
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 17, 2020
CommentsContent: The Buttons feel amazing on this controller, but after some hardcore use (hours and hours of smashing buttons like an elite pro gamer) the same buttons have broken again. The RB button is built with cheap plastic that cannot withstand daily use apparently. It broke on my first controller after a year of use, and luckily i got a new replacement controller of the same for no  price at all. BUt this second controller only lasted a few months before the same button broke. will not be buying again.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 2, 2020
CommentsContent: I wanted to like this controller but there is clearly a manufacturing problem with the face buttons. The first one I got, The (A) button did not register being pressed. I ordered a replacement. The replacement kept getting delayed so I canceled that and just placed a new order entirely. The new order got here today and the (X) button keeps sticking in the downward position. That being said this one may have been on amazon because the box was partially open upon arrival so I'm not sure how much it was tossed around. Anyhow, I am returning this and would recommend people steer clear until the face button problem can be addressed.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2020
CommentsContent: I had the original elite controller and it's been great for a bunch of years now. A few weeks ago, the left hand rubber grip started separating from the the controller like so many others have complained about. There wasn't anything else wrong with it- rechargeable battery was good for 15 hours or so, which is about a week for me, buttons and triggers worked great, no issues with the thumbsticks or accessories, but the grip was annoying. I heard this thing was coming out and tried to play with one at my local MS store. They were sold out and told me it would be two to three weeks before I could even put one in my hands. I saw that Amazon had them in stock and ready for one day shipping, so I just went ahead and did it.I was glad I did! The size and shape are nearly identical, but I really liked the new three-stage trigger stops and the adjustable tension thumbsticks. I also liked that instead of two profiles on a hard switch, I can now have four profiles (including the blank "default") to switch through. It's been more useful than I thought having those. Instead of just "shooter" and "racing" modes, I now have different setups for the type of shooter- 1st person needs faster throws than 3rd person, and I don't have to go into the app between games to reload saved profiles. It's great.I also really like the new charging stand. I don't like that I can't swap battery packs on the fly, but the 40 hour battery life makes it kind of a moot point. It's compact and slick and I like the magnets. It doesn't interfere with the turtle beach headphone adapter, which swapped directly over with no weird gaps or fit issues (another plus).What's less great is that the buttons still don't have a snappy, positive feel to them. They're just like the old ones, which are on the mushy side.Overall, I don't think it's worth it to get the series 2 if your original elite controller is in good condition. I know I wouldn't have done it had the grip not come off. It's not enough of an upgrade otherwise. It's still getting five stars because on its own, it's fantastic, just like what it's replacing. You can't go wrong.

CommentsTitle: Feels premium, but has so many flaws.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2021
CommentsContent: Mine came with horrible srick drift. Some articles mentioned the early batches had quality control issues.Stick drift aside, there were issues that made it uncomfortable. The controller is much heavier than the standard. Most likely due to the massive built in battery and heavier parts. But that means more hand fatigue.There's also the metal sticks. While the adjustable tension is great, the sticks will eat through the rubber shell.The built in battery is back dual edge sword. It's lithium based, so it can maintain a good charge. But it also means you can't swap out the batteries. So you gotta wait for it to recharge. Factor in the lack of replacement battery packs. So you're junking a $160 controller when it dies.Overall it's the most premium controller I've held. Beats the Astro, Scuf, Razer, and Hori in that department. But it has the same flaw as those other premium controllers.When it eventually breaks, it's game over. A kid that plays daily will wear it out. Either the stick sensors, grips, battery, USB plug, or buttons will go.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 8, 2019
CommentsContent: Worse than series 1. 190 bucks and they can’t even include the chat adapter. What a joke

CommentsTitle: BEWARE: STRICT 3 MONTH REPAIR WARRANTY NOW - Microsoft charges $100 to mail it in if anything breaks
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 3, 2020
CommentsContent: I loved the controller until the left bumper button stopped working. I spoke with a Microsoft representative to get it repaired well within the first year of owning it. They were less than helpful and spoke in broken English. What was made clear by the rep is that more than three months of use is a lot of wear and tear for an elite 2 controller. He indicated that my controller was very old according to Microsoft.I don't consider several months of use to be a viable lifespan for en Elite controller. I don't mind being told no per say, but I don't like it when Microsoft acts like I am ridiculous for even calling them about a controller warranty that is more than three months old. I also find their option of $100 up-front payment and mail in for repair or refurb to be less than fair when their product fails within the first few months, well within the first year of the products life.In short, if Microsoft doesn't stand behind the product for more than 90 days and if Microsoft considers their flagship controller to be a 90 day lifespan, then I won't vouch for it either. I am an adult, who plays easy and doesn't abuse electronics....and mine broke. Buy at your own risk.

CommentsTitle: Not just for try-hards, it makes old games great again.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 13, 2021
CommentsContent: This is a real treat. Originally, I felt these controllers were a fad ginned up to hype over price "gamer as a life style" gadgets, or whatever the marketing trash people were soaking up. So, of course, I forgot about it.I started to come around when I got back into COD and I noticed people panic hopping and still able to scratch out kills. At first I thought it was "bumper jumper" or the claw grip, unsure, I sent one of them a message and they confirmed it was the Elite controller.Admittedly, I'm a bit set in my ways, I'm done with memorizing a new control scheme for every game with few exceptions, and I refuse to change my grip. But paddles would make certain tasks much easier or more doable.Little did I know at the time the Elite makes old games with weird or outdated button layouts great again! I fired up the original Saint's Row on Xbox and  immediately changed both the driving and the on foot controls. Now, with the push of a button, I can enjoy this classic, arguably the best in the franchise, with the functionality of the newer games control layout. I still have to switch button profiles between driving or on foot, but it's better than relearning bad and out dated controls just for a nostalgia trip.This control is totally worth the premium price tag. It fully works with all xbox accessories. The built-in battery lasts forever. The customization app is easy to use. The circle d-pad is the best in the industry. This controller is so good I wish devs would add extra paddle functionality options into their games. One recommendation, not sure if this is already a thing, would be to allow the alt button to be toggled instead of just held.

CommentsTitle: Better than any stock controller but FAR to expensive for the issues that plague this controller.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 6, 2020
CommentsContent: Let me start off by saying this a great controller, the battery life blows any rechargeable controller out of the water, its ergonomics are second to none. However, that’s all to be expected since you’re paying a VERY premium price for this controller. My issue I’ve had with this controller all seem to be mechanical, firstly both by the X and B button seem to get randomly “sticky” to where when you press them they don’t fully retract back into possession or do so in a slow manner. I don’t eat when I play and don’t know what caused this. Secondly, the LB bumper only works when its being pressed a certain way and even then sometimes it’ll stop working randomly when I’m holding it. (Heart beat sensor in warzone)The actual ergonomics of the controller is great and when everything does work as intended this is without a doubt the best Xbox controller on the market. The the hair trigger and paddles make for such a different playing experience and it takes getting used to but once I did I‘ll never go back to a regular stock controller. It’s just a shame a controller at this price point has these issues.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 8, 2019
CommentsContent: CAUTION: Trigger lock failure.Because the dead zone for the triggers is too wide, when you set the trigger lock to the shortest level (position 3) the trigger will not work. Resetting/upgrading the firmware don't help.I have to replace it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 14, 2019
CommentsContent: Face buttons on the controller were sticky and unresponsive out of the box. Also the level 3 trigger stops don't register inputs in games. The controller feels really nice in the hands but until they iron out the issues it isn't worth the money.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 23, 2021
CommentsContent: Disconnects frequently and repeatedly and takes your game with it to the grave: Games stutter massively and hitch/hang until this thing reconnects (if it does just that) several seconds later. Unplayable, even with the keyboard as I scramble to save my character yet again. Sometimes it requires powering off and back on to reconnect. And if you sit there like an idiot waiting for it to reconnect, you must now remove it from Bluetooth and reconfigure before you can play again. Good one, Microsoft.Inputs occasionally register twice instantly, most noticeable in menus. Y sometimes fails and, if it doesn't, somehow triggers X instead (??) rarely. RB is 2.5 times louder than LB (3x if pressed from the edge) and squeaks. Sounds cheap. It's also beginning to fail now, just after LT a few weeks ago (no longer works when trigger slider is maxed). The rubber cap for RT's trigger slider fell out long ago due to no adhesion and was finally lost. Did my best to hold it in each session, but I finally snapped due to 6 months of pent-up rage.This controller kills me the most and makes my cheap, bone-stock XB1 controller quiet and reliable in comparison.Seemingly designed to fail after your laughable 90-day warranty so you're forced to buy it again... Ah, if you're still not guillotined, Microsoft wants you to pay $10 for 1–2 week shipping. Nah, man, they're gonna have to pay for it, but now I'm in limbo for a month, for better or worse.Don't be like me and think you'll get lucky. Listen to others' voices and ask if this experience is worth so much of your precious time.Man, did MS show me and spit on afterward. Damn, I need a shower after this one. Easily my worst buy.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 1, 2021
CommentsContent: I really wanted to love this controller. It feels very high quality, and it's the only controller I've found that has 4 "paddles" that let your ring finger and pinky be useful while gaming. Part of the body appears to be made of metal. The D-Pad and joysticks are even made of metal that magnetically pop into their slots. And being able to change the resistance of the joysticks is really nice.But the software is what ruined it. For one, you can only remap the paddles to existing buttons. Even on PC, steam won't recognize those as their own buttons. I had to buy a 3rd part program for them to be actually useful.The connectivity issues were what really killed it! The joysticks frequently "stick" in the sense that the computer will think you kept the joystick in a certain direction after you moved it (sometimes for upwards of 5 seconds). It did this on both computers I tested. I even reinstalled windows on one of them, and it did it after that. So it must be hardware.The controllers feel so nice, but are completely unusable due to the joystick problems.I shouldn't have had so much trust in Microsoft to assume that their $179 controller works.

CommentsTitle: Controller is garbage. reviewed after 2 months. all problems, no fixes. don't waste your money
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 11, 2020
CommentsContent: Well to begin with, coming out of the box I had High expectations. Paddle positions were great. Short Triggers were great, but it was all too good to be true. I'm doing a review on it now, 2 months after I've received my Elite Series 2 Controller. Maybe the problem would stop eventually. It sure didnt... My Original problem started with the 'A' Button. The button double taps constantly, and when you need it to work or when your just trying to press the 'A' Button, it will either double tap or wont respond at all. I thought it could've been something stuck in the button slot, but i cleaned it and no fix. Kinda had to deal with it since I spent the case on it. Now one of my paddle buttons hasn't been responding when I need it to. This is 2 months of use. My Razer Wolverine ultimate lasted me at least 2 years. I bought that one while i was on my deployment and it went through a lot of abuse. There has been sooooooo many times where i just wanted to just smash Elite 2 Controller and just get a new one. I even believe buying a regular $30-50 xbox controller would've been a better buy than. Aesthetically, the controller looks and feels great, but when the controller is literally killing your mood by not working properly, all it does is make you want to throw it as far as you can. Hoping that it lands on the street, so that it could get run over by a cement truck. Dont waste your money like I did. As much as i want to rage out on the controller, I don't. The problems I had with the controller pre-existed before I even got the controller, and also through wear over time, BUT it has only been 2 months and my paddles are already starting to not work properly.Pro:-feel of controller overall-adjustable analogs-adjustable trigger pulls-remapping of buttons is easy-paddle positions are greatCONS:-defective 'A' button-controller wont last long through normal wear-other buttons starting to not work properly after regular use-paddle buttons aren't responding like they use to. If I'm holding the paddle down, it will cutout as if i had let go of the button-the slightest sweat from palms or if you smudged your hand with whatever food your eating, the controller WILL feel slippery on the rubberized handles. not the biggest con, but definitely bothersomeif I'm spending a decent amount of money on a controller, I'd like to expect some kind of decent quality, but there wasn't anything worth the money spent. I literally bought a brand new controller that was broken from the very start, and over time (not a long time) it really hasn't gotten better. It shouldn't have these wear and tear problems at least for a year, not as soon as i get the dam thing. I don't really expect it to last much longer in my case. I will never buy an elite 2 nor will I ever recommend one to a friend, family, coworker, some random viewer from my stream, or to anyone in that case. I tried to work with it as much as possible in order to BELIEVE it was a good controller, but man, it has gotten to the point where I'm just going to get another type of Xbox controller and just trash this one that i have.Don't waste your money. Even if you don't get the same initial problems I had, the controller wont last long. Getting 1-2 year problems through wear and tear in just about 2 months. spending that kind of cash on a controller, you'd expect it to be a tank, not a paper plane.

CommentsTitle: Shockingly bad face buttons and poor quality control
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 31, 2020
CommentsContent: For such an expensive controller, the face buttons are shockingly awful, they feel more like the kind you find on cheap third party controllers. They feel slightly mushy, and will often fail to register if you don't press them firmly at the center of the button. They are significantly worse than the face buttons on the standard controller, which is absolutely baffling for additional cost. Maybe this was a defect, but the face buttons failing to register seems to be a common complaint.Personally, I dislike the general feel of the controller. It is much heavier than the standard controller, and I hate the textured grips. The texture felt nice at first, but there is much more friction against my skin, so my palms get hot and sweaty very quickly, which was never an issue with the standard controller.It is worth mentioning that using the paddles and creating profiles on PC REQUIRES a Microsoft/Xbox account and installation of (free) software that can only be obtained from the Microsoft Store.General quality control also seems fairly poor, one of the paddles I received was defective, and won't stay in the slots, and doesn't click properly. It looks identical to the other, so I suspect it wasn't magnetized properly.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 10, 2020
CommentsContent: Purchased the controller in May, now it's December and my thumbsticks are already developing crazy amounts of drift and the left one is largely unresponsive. Thought they would fix these issues in gen 2 but apparently not. These issues actually developed faster than my previous Elite gen 1 controller (multiple broken bumpers, unresponsive buttons, stick drift).Really disappointed. It feels really well crafted, and that would lead me to rate it higher than a 1 star but the absolutely obscene price merits nothing more than that.Fortunately they've seemed to upgrade the factory warranty of 90 DAYS!!!!!! to a full year. Just glad I bought this with a card that has additional warranty protection because I'm sure this won't be the only time within the next year I'm submitting a warranty claim.Avoid this controller until they fix these issues

CommentsTitle: I prefer my razer wolverine after about 30 hours of play.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 9, 2019
CommentsContent: It has some awesome features that the Razer doesn't, however I hate the paddles which is a problem. They are too close together and on the same plane, when I go to switch my weapon I end up holstering on accident because of the travel and lack of tactile feedback. As for the app it's great but I thought switching buttons would be more useful than it is, however on diablo or RPGs the added shift function is probably real nice. The app is my favorite part for sure, the controller feels sturdy and the trigger stops are amazing. The tension adjustment on the sticks are nice but the highest setting doesn't feel right when rotating radially like it stops at the horizontal or vertical axis. Maybe itll be smoother after breaking it in more? The case and dock are really nice but the accessories could be better. The high stick is way taller, almost too tall. The two 360 sticks? Meh... Why not a mid rise xone stick and a mid rise dome stick? I wish all the buttons had a mouse click mechanism because it feels better on the wolverine.Overall I prefer the Wolverine button and trigger feel and placement no contest. The wolverine has two extra trigger buttons on top with mouse click feel that were absolutely the best and I miss them on the Elite so much. I like the Elite 2 stick low and medium tension as well as the xone sticks but not the others. The Elite app is better than razer's. The Razer feels better in the hands to me. I really am trying to get used to the Elite 2 and I'll keep at it but so far I like the Wolvie better, 8.8 points for the Wolvie and 7.2 for the Elite 2. I'll update after a month.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 10, 2019
CommentsContent: Poor Quality, Excellent FeaturesRight stick drifting away out of the box. Sending in for a replacement. ETA on a replacement is 1-2 months.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 11, 2021
CommentsContent: This controller is by FAR the best controller I have ever used when working properly.  But that's the problem these controllers don't last and even if you buy a warranty good luck getting a good replacement because it's the same recycled controllers that other people are returning for the same problems.  Bumpers on this controller are worse than the Series One version of this controller.  Stick drift is a very common problem with all Xbox controllers this one is 100% better than the regular $60 controllers, but within a year I guarantee you will have a problem if you use this controller more than 4 times a week.  I got this controller delivered to me on September 19, 2020 and its currently January 11, 2021 and finally decided to write a review.  Mid December is when I stopped using this controller because the bumpers don't register and left stick drifts left consistently which throws me off because I play Rocket League.  I had a Xbox One Elite Controller Series One and that controller lasted me 2 years whereas I have been through 3 of these Series Two controllers all in a 2 years.  Truly pathetic and I can't warranty claim them due to the fact that the warranty is only "90 days".  If these controllers were warrantied for more than a year Microsoft would definitely be out of business.  All in all don't buy if you want longevity out of your controller otherwise you will be committing to a $180 subscription about every 6-8 months.

CommentsTitle: Button problems right out of the box.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 26, 2020
CommentsContent: The first one of these I ordered had an issue where the A button would stick down sometimes.  It happened immediately in the first game I played with it.  I returned it and the replacement also had an A button issue.  This time the button would bottom out and not always register.This controller is supposed to be the best, yet it appears to be plagued with issues.

CommentsTitle: Buttons  unresponsive and therefore controller is useless
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 15, 2020
CommentsContent: Started to notice that RB wasn't responsive.  At first thought I was doing something wrong but used the Microsoft controller test functionality and I can see it has problems.  I usually use the paddles underneath for A and B, so hadn't noticed much during gameplay.  Started testing those and A and B weren't responding consistently either.  Disappointing as the I think the design is great and if it worked as designed it would be a 5 star review.  I threw it back in the closet and went back to my original series 1 which seems much better.  The item is useless if you can't trust the buttons will respond.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 8, 2020
CommentsContent: Why am I paying for a 200$ controller for again? Oh for it to work, nah just to look at apparently. I bought this controller because I wanted to have a controller that was not cheaply made or flimsy.Except thats not what this controller is. It seems to have the same type of care put into it as a 60$ controller. It works fine, until I play a game where reactions are key like for honor, Call of duty, Dark souls etc. Then for whatever reason when I push a combination of buttons or hold the controller a certain way, it turns off.I have never seen a product that cost so much money, so cheaply made. Yes it is just a controller, but if its just like a 60$ controller why did I fork out more money for a controller that will not even function properly?Do NOT buy this. You would be better off replacing a 60$ controller every couple of months, rather than replacing a 200$ controller every two months. I dont know if I have a defective controller or something, but this is completely unacceptable.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 13, 2020
CommentsContent: I am in a bit of shock at how absolutely horrible this controllers wireless capabilities are. First off, Bluetooth is horrendous. It will connect to bluetooth for a quick moment, lag whatever you're playing, then shut off. I've tried updating my drivers, restarting my pc, updated the controllers firmware still nothing. I then went out to bestbuy and bought a wireless adapter hoping it would benefit. The game no longer lags before disconnecting, but will still disconnect very quickly. It's a damn shame this thing costs $180 when it does not even stay connected wireless. Save your money and find another controller to use.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2020
CommentsContent: I had the extremely common issue that Microsoft refused to address of the rubber grips coming off my Series 1, as well as a sticky B button. I never liked the traditional controller and felt the Elite series was much more responsive and attenuated. I decided to dive in cash in the Series 2 and don't regret it thus far.The build seems more sturdy, and the charging dock is a nice feature. I don't think the grip problem will occur on this controller as it seems it's more of a coating than an actual rubber grip. The controller also feels more balanced in my hand with just the right amount of weight. I also really like the shorter throw option on the triggers as well as the adjustable tensioner on the joysticks. If you want a solid controller that you'll respect, this is the way to go. 4 stars because it's a 1/3 the cost of a the console, though, if not even more than that.Pros:Seemingly resolves grip separation issues that plagued the Series 1Adjustable joystick tensionShorter throw option on triggersBetter weight distribution in the controllerRechargeable battery with dockCons:PriceyMagnetic pieces are prone to detach under certain circumstances, but not as much as the Series 1

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 17, 2020
CommentsContent: I'm very conflicted about how to review the Series 2. As a controller, it's fantastic, which I'll get into. Unfortunately, Microsoft clearly does not put enough focus into making sure these controllers are built to last.Contrary to the experiences of my others, my original Elite lasted five full years before dieing on me. That made it very worth the price! However, I'm on my third Series 2, as the other two both developed unplayable stick drift in the left stick. One was replaced by Amazon, the other by Microsoft. Note that, while I highly recommend this controller, you'll probably have a much, much better life span from it if you're willing to replace the thumbstick components yourself or through someone else, because Microsoft seems to put very little towards some of the internals.As far as mechanics, I think it's great. I prefer the paddles over the original, they provide a firmer response and are less prone to misclicks. Adjustable thumbstick tension is fantastic, even though the range of tension isn't that huge. At full tension, I think it feels quite nice, but at the lowest tension, it's far too sensitive for me.Though I respect the tiered trigger stops, they're unnecessary for most used, I think. The bottom stop is a very short stop, which many would probably like, though I think the middle one is far better. I don't think I ever realized how much a difference the front facing textures make, they really do feel nice. One weird gripe I have is that the Guide button has been turned from a "soft", depressable button to a harder, short click. It's obviously very minimal, to the point where I hardly think of it.I wish they'd improved the directional pad, as I still think the 360's d-pad feels much better. Sometimes it kinda feels like you have to search out the particular spot to press on, because it doesn't come out of the controller much and each arm of the d-pad is rather small. The variant you're offered to change the feel doesn't really help much, either. Fortunately, the triggers, bumpers, face buttons, thumbstick clicks, paddles, and pause / back buttons all feel both familiar and comfortable.It's certainly worth mentioning that the accessories and the controller case are all very quality, and the case in particular is very useful. I would definitely say they're worth whatever extra few dollars they cost you.

CommentsTitle: Best controller ever made, I use this exclusively for PC gaming (get reWASD software)
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 7, 2019
CommentsContent: I don't even own an XBOX, but I love this thing for single-player PC action-adventure and RPG games (Witcher 3, Tomb Raider, GTA V, Red Dead 2, Hitman, Batman, etc).This is made superbly well, is easy to customize the analog sticks, and the paddles on the back are awesome.Make sure to get a program called reWASD to customize the controller in ways beyond the XBOX app. I put F12 and PrintScreen on two of the paddles for screenshots in Steam and Nvidia, and have used the paddles for other keys depending on the game.I was sick of dealing with third-party pairing programs for my DualShock 4 on PC, and this thing just connects in one second via Bluetooth and works on everything. I love it!

CommentsTitle: Controllers are fine, but actually receiving them is not.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 11, 2019
CommentsContent: I've ordered this controller a total of 3 times. I had originally ordered 2 controllers, 1 for me, and 1 for my man. The first order arrived with 1 elite series 2 and an obviously worn elite series 1 in a series 2 box so I returned the 1 and reordered the series 2. This time when I opened the box I worried because the package seal was broken so I though they may have sent another series 1. Luckily it was the series 2 we wanted, but it's missing the cord for the charging dock.I understand that these controllers are in high demand, but this kind of quality control is unacceptable.All in all, the controllers themselves are very nice. Lighter than the series 1 with smaller paddles and 3 paddle configuration settings.Only issue I forsee in the future is not being able to switch the batteries out. So if the controller cant hold a charge, I'm assuming I'll have to get a whole new controller unless I'm mistaken.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2020
CommentsContent: Unfortunately, Microsoft didn't seem to learn as much as they claimed to from the Elite Controller 1 debacle. This is obviously a high-end controller that feels nice and has a good weight to it. The paddles on the back are still entirely useless, but otherwise everything is very pleasing to the touch. The problem is, like always, quality control. The face buttons in particular seem prone to error, judging from the reviews, and mine are no different. From day 1, the A and Y button do not work unless pressed harder than one should have to. It's obvious that Microsoft is using the same cheap membrane switches that everybody knows and loves from the regular controllers. I'm going to be returning mine for a replacement, but if that one is also like this, I will just send it back altogether.Poor effort.Update for July 2020I've gone through two returns now. The first one I received had non-functional shoulder buttons, and I just received another replacement that had the same issue as the original, probably worse. I give up. Unacceptable.

CommentsTitle: Good enough to make sad when it inevitably breaks
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 27, 2020
CommentsContent: I have two Elite Series 1 controllers that I still use, one was initially defective but otherwise ok after a few years. I got my first Elite Series 2 last Xmas and the left hair trigger almost immediately started having problems. When the right bumper also got unresponsive I sent it away for warranty repair (while I still could) and ordered a second one, b/c frankly I can't live w/o paddles for FPS games anymore.Welp, got my new $180 controller today (ordered w/ a CC that gives extended warranties b/c I know I'll need it) and opened it up and... the right hair trigger simply doesn't work at all. No registering of a trigger pull at all. So I suppose I'll be shipping *two* Elite controllers back to Microsoft this weekend. It's a shame these things are so good when they do work, b/c they're incredibly expensive and finicky.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 14, 2020
CommentsContent: The Elite 2 offers the most advanced features any controller can offer. From it's 2-3 Day battery life for the average gamer or even most competitive, you can count on Xbox to not let you down during those high intense FPS moments of Apex Legends or Fortnite!Features like the button mapping lets you have complete control over every button action as well as four extra paddles on the back. Building in Fortnite never seemed so effortless and swapping weapons or a quick heal while never having to move your thumbs from the joysticks can give you that edge in the heat of a 3v1 situation! Other technical features like the Joystick response curves and hairline triggers allow a complete custom feel so you can get a that perfect shot and quick reflex every single time.Swappable thumbstick and D-pad are included so you can game how you want. whether you need something quick for flicking when doing those quick adjustments in Tony Hawk Pro, or a tall technical stick for Fine aiming for any FPS game. All swappable pieces are magnetic so you never have to worry about losing them.This controller is a bit on the heavy side, but for the amount of features and the battery life I wouldn't expect something light from such a quality build, it never gets tiring holding it and the grip that wraps around the sides back and fourth definitely help. Xbox you outdid yourself and rate this a 10/10

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 12, 2020
CommentsContent: I've already had one warranty replacement and it's difficult getting the second replacement.  I had the typical bumper issue and the replacement has both a bumper issue and a sticky x button.  Very disappointing considering the cost and how much usage non-elite controllers hold up to in comparison.When you do get a replacement - it seems like they send you a refurbished controller that has a warranty period that is closed even though your original controller is still under warranty.  be prepared to have to jump through additional hoops to try to get additional warranty claims submitted (you'll most likely need to)side note - why can't you change the rear triggers to map to non-xbox buttons like keystrokes on pc?  It seems like a lost opportunity for making the controller way more usable.

CommentsTitle: Just out of warranty and is already failing
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 29, 2020
CommentsContent: I wouldn't bother with this controller. The Elite 1 controller has better build quality. I play competitive Rocket League(2400+ hours) and I cannot use this controller because the left stick doesn't register inputs half the time. Causing me to do a double jump instead of a flip. I can instantly switch to a One S controller or my old Elite and everything is fine.Edit: Decided to pull the controller back out since I stopped using it months ago. Came to find out they extended the warranty to 1 year. But here it is. Too late. This controller probably has less than 20 hours of use or something and pressing up on the left stick does nothing now and it's out warranty.Just avoid it and buy a regular Xbox One controller. They're some-how more durable than Elite controllers. I've had three Elite Series 1 controllers and now this one and they've all failed miserably...  out of warranty dates.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 15, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought this controller on May 9th 2020 by June 1st i finally figured out my problem was a bad controller didnt last one month , the left stick was auto moving forward you tap it and it stops then does the exact same thing again over and over , not to good quality for a controller with a $274.00 price tag , contacted amazon no problems ship it back we will ship another , waited for the controller it didnt come in on 11th as expected now they are saying another 2 weeks , got my 2nd controller in id say after 3 weeks same problems with stick drift about to return it once again

CommentsTitle: Same awful quality as the old Elite; dead after 6 months
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 19, 2020
CommentsContent: Once again, I have gone through an Elite controller in less than a year.  Overall, I've suffered through the bad design of 6 Elite controllers in 6 years.  I'm really not a heavy gamer, and I don't mash the buttons like a gorilla, but I bought my controller around the first of the year and it didn't even last 6 months.  The right button no longer fires reliably and is reminiscent of the cheap button design used in the old Xbox Elite controller.  $180 for a piece of junk that breaks after 5 months.  Thanks Microsoft.  Never again.  You've got me for over $1,000 in now-broken controllers.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 6, 2019
CommentsContent: I got this controller November 5 and after playing with the controller settings I realized that the hair triggers are not working (smallest trigger pull setting). They don’t even register feedback when playing with the dead zones on the controller app. Edit: I got a replacement sent to me and I gotta say I like it a lot. If you are trying to figure out if you wanna get the elite series one or series two, save your doe and get this one.

CommentsTitle: Fantastic controller for PC gaming - BUT you're likely to encounter stick drift
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2020
CommentsContent: This is a fantastic piece of hardware. It's packaged nicely, the hardware feels nice, the buttons feel great, the paddles are very useful...However, this controller is plagued with the same problem that the Series 1 controller had: analog stick drift. I noticed after a couple of months of use that this controller's left and right sticks don't snap back to their exact center. Check out the attached photo to see for yourself: those sticks are not centered as detected by Windows, but they're in a totally neutral position from a hardware perspective.Microsoft Support says that the controller would have to be sent away for repairs, and that costs $90. No thank you. The kind support tech also said that some people have solved this by increasing the tension on the sticks. I've tried that, and it doesn't work for me.Stay away from this controller. It's unfortunate that this $180 piece of premium hardware has such a fundamental issue. I expected better from Microsoft.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 28, 2020
CommentsContent: Up until recently, this controller has been an amazing purchase and I have enjoyed playing on it. But unfortunately after 5 months of very casual gaming, the left stick is now drifting and causes an almost unusable controller. I genuinely have treated this controller extremely well and take very careful care of it (keep in case, never put down hard, etc). After reaching out to Xbox, I found out that they only offer a 3 month warranty on a very expensive piece of hardware! Pretty ridiculous, so as much as I wanted to write a good review on this product, unfortunately I can not endorse it knowing the issues that A TON of people are having and Xbox's inability to stand behind their products.

CommentsTitle: Fantastic feeling controller with some absolutely terrible build issues
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 10, 2020
CommentsContent: Second controller here. First one had the unresponsive A button issue, so I put in for an exchange. The first controller had an issue where frequently button presses of the A button simply would not register while playing games or using a testing app. It typically took a second or several re-presses for it to finally click. The second controller seems to have a similar problem, but I've only been able to reproduce it a couple of times thus far, so it may simply be an issue with breaking in the gamepad, or I just have terrible luck. I'm probably keeping it for the following reasons if I can find a good workaround or fix:The Feel: The controller actually has a solid grip, looks nice, and has a good balance of customization options and tactile response. It's a bit heavier than I like, but the tension adjustments on the joysticks are pretty good, and the interchangeable paddles and thumb-sticks are a really good design decision.Responsiveness: Solid response times when using wired or the Xbox wireless adapter. Bluetooth is no-good however. Signal loss/latency seems to increase when using Bluetooth on multiple devices, even when the controller is right next to the Bluetooth antenna.Being able to remap the paddles (and any other buttons) is a feature I love, but I'd like it if I could remap them to other, non-gamepad buttons. I don't have the largest hands, so the paddles in reach without significantly changing the grip is really nice.

CommentsTitle: Premium feel but will it stand the test of time?
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 5, 2019
CommentsContent: I avoided the prior iteration of this controller due to the numerous posts around the internet questioning its quality. I took a gamble on the new version due to the updated connectivity, charging, and *fingers crossed* quality.It only came today (11/5/19), but using it for a few minutes (paired with an xbox one adapter on my computer) was definitely a dream. I still have to get used to the paddles but I can already tell my hands will not be cramping as much. The modular nature of the d-pad, paddles, and analog sticks is interesting. Hopefully the R1/L1 bumpers don't become modular unintentionally.I'm most excited about the quality of the d-pad because the various 2D retro-style sidescrollers I enjoy playing truly benefit from that precision that I never really had on other Xbox controllers.Anyway, I plan to update the review if I come across any issues, but my initial thoughts are very positive!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 9, 2020
CommentsContent: I had the first Elite controller and I loved it.  It worked like a champ, felt very premium and really was a great controller.  I was very excited when the Elite 2 came out.  It should be the controller I love, but improved and USB C charging which I was looking forward to as well.When I got it, it felt great.  They truly upped their game on how it feels and plays.  It felt like exactly what I wanted.  But this controller has some significant reliability issues.Within 3 months, I was getting SIGNIFICANT drift on both of my joysticks on this.  It was unusable.  I figured I got a lemon, so I reached out to Microsoft support.  They were incredibly unhelpful and just told me to buy another one.  The warranty on these is absolute garbage.  Think a premium controller comes with a premium warranty and is backed by the company that makes it?  Think again.  Buy it again after it just fails after 3 months?  No chance I'm doing that.After explaining the situation to the reseller I bought it from and arguing with them about it I got them to finally replace it for me.  But guess what happens again about 3 months later?  Both joysticks start drifting really badly again.There have been articles out there about how Microsoft has extended the warranty on this controller now because of these issues, but good luck getting them to honor that.  It's honestly been shocking how bad their support has been, and now I've had 2 of these extremely expensive controllers fail on me.Absolute garbage that no one should buy.

CommentsTitle: Don’t waste your money, you can do better.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 2, 2020
CommentsContent: Microsoft needs better quality control, these controllers are hot garbage out of the box, I’ve had 3 now, and yet they all either defective on arrival or have issues not long afterward. All 3 had major issues with buttons sticking, one had an issue with the A button not responding, the other two with varying levels of stick drift. The last one I bought lasted until about a month outside the return window and then started showing faults. A button stick and left stick drift. 180$ US for their most advanced controller... laughable when you might get 2-3 months of daily usage before it exhibits an issue, if not DOA. Love the feel of it, and while the last one worked fine for a while, it lasted 1/10th the time of its xb1 counterparts. Anyone reading this should consider other options before spending money on something like this, there are more reliable options on the market with better quality control.

CommentsTitle: Would rate a 0 if I could
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 24, 2020
CommentsContent: The controller started off great but I'm not a heavy gamer and it's only a couple of months old and already there is drift in the left stick and some of the buttons don't register reliably. Disappointed to say the least for this price point. I ordered this partly because I was sick of replacing regular controllers due to drift and unreliable buttons and this has the same problem.Now I can't even get support from Microsoft as their support site doesn't let you register accessories (even if they cost nearly as much as a console) and they won't let me talk to anyone because all the options I've tried say personal support is not available for this device and they push me to their awful virtual assistant or to post on their unorganized forums.DO NOT BUY THIS or if you do make sure you know how to buy the extended warranty.

CommentsTitle: A great set of improvements to the best controller design out there - with a critical flaw.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 17, 2020
CommentsContent: Summarypros: builds on all the things that made the original great and addresses some series 1 issuescons: like the series 1, has its own manufacturing flawsDetailed ReviewThis controller improves upon the already fantastic elite series 1 in core ways:- even better build feel and quality (weighted well, "feels premium"- rounded and slightly heavier paddles (v1 paddles could cut into your fingers a tad)- redesigned grip (to address grip issues in the first iteration- more tactile grip on the sticks and alternate sticks- 3 points of trigger setting- 3 configurable mapping slots- very slick charging dockAll in all the designers really understood why the original one was good, what parts about it were annoying, and made solid decisions.--- However ---The original series controller has a really nasty flaw in the way its grip and adhesive were manufactured - leading to grips falling off within an unreasonable time frame.  And it looks like the series 2 might have a few production problems of its own.The face buttons (and to some degree the home button) are an interesting "glass like" smooth shell but their sensors do not attach properly to the control chips - this means that even when the button "taps" as if you have registered a button tap but no press is received in game.  It seems like you have to very carefully press down on a 90 degree angle to guarantee the press works, and some buttons (probably based on the angle of your hand) are more prone to this than others.  The A button is by far the worst offender - it fails all the time.Doing some research this also looks like it is an issue that effects many others as well.If not for this 1 critical issue, the product would get 5 stars in a heartbeat.  I really do hope they fix the problem in future batches so fewer people receive duds.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 29, 2020
CommentsContent: I am literally two days out of warranty and I have absolutely fatal stick drift. The controller acts like I'm pressing the left stick up when I am not. It constantly interferes with games and I have exhausted all the settings options to adjust it - without success. All my Microsoft controllers have eventually developed this issue, but this is the FASTEST ONE. Which is outrageous since the Elite Series 2 is supposed to be the best of the best. My 360 controller lasted years and years before developing problems, and my Xbox One controller made it almost a year. Now this one makes it 3 months? RIDICULOUS. DO NOT BUY.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 2, 2020
CommentsContent: I purchased this as a birthday gift for my husband. He really wanted the Elite controller but after learning that Series 2 was coming out he decided to wait. And he's so glad he did. This controller is amazing! He's an avid gamer (Destiny and Monster Hunter are his biggest ones) and this controller allows him to customize everything about his gameplay. He said it was one of the best gifts I've ever gotten him so it deserves 5 stars!!Update 9/24/2020The controller turned off during game play and will not power back on. My husband treats this controller like gold. Very carefully. Never drops it & always puts it away in the case. When he hooks it up to the system wyh the cable only a few buttons show as responding even though the xbox logo on the controller doesn't come on. This is ridiculous. Nearly $200 and just dies in 8 months??? Don't waste your money.

CommentsTitle: Best controller money can buy with ONE major flaw
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 8, 2020
CommentsContent: First of all, it’s a fantastic controller. It has amazing software remapping and the best thing over the Series 1 is the adjustable tension sticks. Also a ton of other features not found om any other controller.However, the analog sticks are incredibly LOOSE, and to compensate there is a very large built-in dead zone. This was the case both units I received from amazon. It is worse than any stock controller I’ve ever used, including the original Xbox one controller. Even my $35 DualShock 4 has sticks that return EXACTLY to the center when released and they don’t wobble at all.There is no competitive gaming situation where a controller with sticks like this is usable. This is absolutely inexcusable for a controller that costs almost as much as the console itself. I’ve returned both the controller and the replacement. Have very little hope in Microsoft’s ability to make a decent controller anymore.

CommentsTitle: Not a Smart Buy, you just have to replace it in a month or 2
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 15, 2020
CommentsContent: Do not Buy! If you do, go to Microsoft.com. And even then make sure you get a warranty! So far I have had to replace ours once, and was about to again because once again having problems with the buttons, and lag in the controllers. Think ill just get my money back now after reading that so so many other people have the same issues....till this day too! Me and my fiancée both bought one a peice so in total all 4 controllers I've bought here have messed up within a month or 2! No controllers I have ever had messed up this quick. They atleast lasted 2 to 3 yrs with no lag, no issues. Why is something that cost twice as much as a normal controller a peice of trash? Microsoft needs to fix this NOW! I love the controller honestly, I just wish they would've made them right the first time. They say its a bad batch...well must be the whole line because everyone is sending them back, replacing them multiple times, and still have the same problems. I dont even know what to do...risk buying them from the actual site and them having the same issue or go for the scuff. Which I don't like as much as the elite. I just want 2 good working, long lasting elite series 2 controllers  but looks like it isn't happening anytime soon. ☹😖

CommentsTitle: My new controller for switch and PC
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 1, 2020
CommentsContent: I struggled at first trying to connect it to the nintendo switch through the 8bitdo adapter, it turned out I had to get the updated version of the firmware on both the controller and the adapter, after that, it is my favorite controller ever, I was used to the switch controller and always bothered when I tried to play a game on PC because of the button layout difference; this controller solved that, feels good when you hold it (maybe a little too heavy tho), easy to customize with the magnetic joy sticks, and I find really hard to find something to complain about it except for the price, this is a luxury item, you are over paying for what you get, but if this is not a problem for you, don't think about it too much.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 15, 2019
CommentsContent: Update: Everything I said below is true but the replacement has now developed “drift” where the left stick pushes right without being touched. Makes some games hard to say the least.For a product this expensive to be so unreliable doesn’t cut it. I took it into the Microsoft Store and they said I’d need to take a video of this happening to prove it. That’s kinda hard!It’s a fabulous controller in so many ways, but life is too short to keep returning the darned thing.I should mention they had some quality control issues with this and I had to try twice before I got one that worked. However, now I have, this thing is just quality.It’s perfectly weighted, all controls feel sturdy and it just, well, feels “nice” to use.No, I haven’t suddenly become a world class video game player, but this does add an extra dimension to gameplay. It wasn’t cheap but my god, I love it!

CommentsTitle: Cool controller, but not worth the price.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 4, 2019
CommentsContent: It feels really nice, it is lighter than the first controller. There are new options added to the controller that make it more superior than its original generation. The grips feel better too, overall just feels more natural in the hand. However I do dislike that they only send you, one, yes one TALL magnetic stick. Like, why? Some players play with the tall sticks (like me) and without having two of them it feels awkward. You cannot even use the ones from your old elite controller because they are designed different. Other than that, everything feels more tactile too.

CommentsTitle: Awesome Controller Until RB Stopped Registering
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 8, 2020
CommentsContent: This controller is amazing. Construction is nice and it feels way better in my hand than the regular Xbox controller. The recharge ability with USB C is so nice. I bought this controller in February 2020, and now in July 2020 I am having issues with RB not registering and sometimes double registering. At first I thought it was lag in game, but it is clear that it is the controller and it's getting worse. From what I am reading online this is a common issue. This shouldn't happen for a $170 controller.UPDATE 11/15/2020: The double input from RP and not registering went away for awhile but now it's back worse than ever. Very frustrating.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 20, 2021
CommentsContent: Only been couple months and the RB button and A button are starting to stick and not work on occasions. It was listed as "used Like New" but after using now it feels as it's been used for a long time. Feels very worn...I noticed the D pad felt very worn out and loose at first but thought I'd roll dice and keep it. Now I'm stuck with a remote that's "like new" but feels years old, with stuck/worn buttons. I take extremely good care of my stuff too, so I know this is not from me. My Series X is my baby (see pictures). I have a feeling this remote was MUCH older than it was listed to be. Would not recommend buying used from here.

CommentsTitle: Best Xbox controller out there, bar none!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2020
CommentsContent: I was tired of getting slaughtered in Battlefield 5, and was told by several of my gaming buddies that this controller would make me more killy.  Well, it does. I also added a high rise Kontrolfreek to the right joystick (the one you aim with) which provides a much higher degree of precision and control when aiming in FPS games. The weight of the controller is nice too. It feels very solid in hand and the texture on the grips helps keep it in place. It has no removable battery, but the battery life in this controller is impressive! Depending on usage, it will last 5 to 7 days without a charge if you play every day like I do. The additional paddles are cool, but I haven't found a legit use for them yet. (I just haven't taken the time to really explore how to use them). Overall, this is definitely the best Xbox controller you can buy.

CommentsTitle: 90 day warranty is sub standard for this price
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 7, 2020
CommentsContent: I didnt check the length of coverage for this warranty (I SHOULD HAVE) and it is only 90 days.  It says a lot that the company only guarantees a product for 90 days, which means they expect it to break around day 120 and you  can buy a new controller.  However, you can pay 45 dollars and have a 3yr warranty coverage...which also says a lot.  I should have known better I am an IT hardware guru which in this case worked against me because I assumed industry standard by association with MSRP and the microsoft brand.  It just goes to show your mom was right, always read the fine print because while its a great controller it wasnt worth about a dollar a day and now its junk.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 24, 2020
CommentsContent: So first I love the feel of the elite controller. It’s very responsive and the paddles are great for sliding and juking in games. BUT only buy one if your feeling really lucky if you get a good one you will love it. I am personally waiting for my 4th replacement in a row to be processed because of button and joystick issues with the controllers. They have terrible quality control. Really at this point I would gladly get my money back if I could and just get a design lab controller for a quarter the price.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 7, 2020
CommentsContent: i really wanted to love this controller. but the truth is that one of the toggle switches takes a lot more effort to engage than the rest. i can not use the top left paddle with confidence.  if you're going to pay this much, it better be perfect. it's nice and the thumbsticks feel like they are gliding on the smoothest surface as you go around. the weight feels a bit heavy and after extended playing periods, you'll notice it. no sticky buttons! and I really liked the three settings for the trigger stops. if you get a good controller it's perfect but the one I have leaves my confidence lacking. nothing worse than trying to use your paddle during a raid just to find out you didn't give the button enough push.

CommentsTitle: Myriad of issues for a premium price.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 25, 2020
CommentsContent: I had been eyeballing this controller for a while but held off after reading of all the issues the series 1 had. After seeing only brief mentions of the A button sticking and that being a quick fix I broke down and bought one.I didn't have a lot of time to use it initially and after setting it up I only used it sparingly for about a month. When I finally got around to using it in earnest I found the A button frequently didn't register when pressed and would sometimes stop registering as pressed when held in. I was using it on my PC so I fired up the XBox accessories app it uses as well as Windows' built in game controller software to view my inputs. I found that, yes, the A button wouldn't register about 5% of the time it was pressed and when held in it would frequently stop registering if my thumb moved slightly off center. Comparing it to the base XBox One controller the buttons on this model do feel looser. You can notably jiggle them around with your thumb a lot more than I've ever been able to with any controller. I assume this doesn't help.I wanted to just return it to Amazon and recoup my $180 but I had just missed the month-long return window.I registered the controller with Microsoft and it was within warranty. This series had so many problems with it at this point that Microsoft had implemented a no-questions-asked replacement policy with these. So I opened a ticket and sent it off to Microsoft for replacement. The replacement arrived a couple of weeks later. I fired it up, updated the firmware and promptly opened the game controller software to test the buttons. This brand new controller had the exact same issues on the exact same button but it occurred much more often, around 10-20% of presses did not work. Again, I had not even used it at all up to this point and it was worse than the original I had sent in.I sent that one back as well. When the new new one finally arrived I tested the buttons and this time it was better... sort of. Now the A button registers every input which is good BUT the A, B and Y buttons sometimes fail to register as held when your thumb moves while holding them. As I was fiddling with it a brand new issue popped up that was actually the worst one yet. The right thumbstick sometimes feels rough, like something is under it and it will stick way off center. Adjusting the tension on the stick doesn't really do anything. It doesn't happen all the time but every few minutes it feels like a mild grinding/rubbing and the stick will just stick wherever it is. Additionally, its neutral position is always just off of center unless manually adjusted to the middle.I feel completely ripped off. This controller is $180 and you have no guarantee it will work right at all. Even relying on the 90 warranty through Microsoft is a gamble because you might get sent one that is actually worse. And once those 90 days are up you are done (unless you want to spend more money to gamble further). That's where I am. I have a $180 paperweight.

CommentsTitle: Great at First - Starts Failing After 5 Months
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 21, 2020
CommentsContent: This controller is a complete scam, either accidentally through poor engineering or intentionally with planned obsolescence.I primarily used this device to play Rocket League on PC. I play with my boost bound to the left bumper and after only about 5 months the bumper is beginning to fail. Every time it starts acting up, you must remove the faceplate and attempt to clean any dust out around the button and play with the inserts. This must be done several times a day or get used to playing with the faceplate off.
