Very convenient their warranty is only 90 days as their buttons become unreliable after around 5 months.Pros:- A lot of Customization- Comfortable (mostly)- PC support- Magnetic charging stand- Case and accessoriesCons:- Must connect over USB to configure anything- Reconnecting to Bluetooth after connecting via USB requires removing the controller from Bluetooth devices and restarting your computer- Left bumper failing after 5 months use- Comfort (Get used to playing with the faceplate off for frequent and easy troubleshooting)- Horribly short 90-day warranty and no offer for an extended warranty (By contrast, Razer offers 1 year on all of their controllers even though they're notorious for their terrible quality control. I went through 4 or 5 in a couple of years back in the 360 days.)- Too expensive- Difficult to take apart (Faceplate attached by clips and adhesive, not screws. Screws on the inside are all torx.)- Microsoft wants $100 outside of the 90-day warranty to repair or replace

CommentsTitle: Over Priced. Defective parts. Short 90 day warranty.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 25, 2020
CommentsContent: Make sure you're comfortable with the warranty terms before forking over almost two hundred dollars for a controller that is made out of cheap plastic parts. Microsoft has limited the warranty to 90 days. Thats 90 days for a controller with a built-in battery and defective bumpers which notoriously break. My controller bumper and trigger came loose after 3-4 months of light usage. Microsoft response is that they've agreed to fix it if I pay an additional one hundred dollars. Thats an additional one hundred dollars to change out the cheap plastic parts on a new controller I paid almost two hundreds dollars for a few months ago. If Microsoft can't guarantee these controllers for at least one year, for how much they're charging,  to me its just isn't worth it.

CommentsTitle: Controller? great. But do not buy from JRsourcing.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2021
CommentsContent: JRsourcing sold me a used and repackaged controller under the claim that it was "new." Same price as a new one, packaging seemed intact, but amazon was out of stock, so I, for my first time ever have used a third party seller. (won't happen again)Clue 1: The paddles were preinstalled on the controller, which they should not have been. They come placed into the slots for them in the controller case.Clue 2: the 2 week xbox game pass ultimate code that comes with them was redeemed already.Contacted amazon yesterday, they passed me along to a messaging account from JR sourcing.I'll update if anything comes of it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 14, 2020
CommentsContent: No recomiendo este control en absoluto. Veamos, los materiales de elaboración, de lujo; al tacto muy cómodo y ergonómico, muy buena sensación. Lo compré en septiembre y un par de meses más tarde la entrada de audio dejó de funcionar, y ahora en junio el RB ha muerto; por este precio yo esperaría un control que me durara al menos el mismo tiempo que la consola. Es un producto demasiado caro y se avería demasiado rápido; teniendo otras alternativas en el mercado más baratas y muchísimo más duraderas como el Razer Wolverine que lo compré hace 2 años y el Power A Fusion Pro que compré hace 1 año.... No lo recomiendo bajo ninguna circunstancia! Jamás compraría este producto nuevamente. Mi entusiasmo de agotó muy pronto! Pésima compra!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 5, 2020
CommentsContent: Spending the extra money was the best decision! This controller is worth every penny if you’re a serious gamer.Feels amazing in the hands, both joysticks and directional pad are MAGNETICALLY interchangeable; very easy and smooth.3 Level Trigger adjustment is amazing in shooter games, hair trigger, medium pull and full pull.The case is top notch, and holds all the extra buttons and charging stand. Also, the charging stand is magnetic (strong), you can charge the controller directly, or set it on the charger, or there’s even a little slot for the cable to go into the case and charge it while it’s closed; they thought through everything.The customization is done directly on Xbox natively, not complicated at all unless you go advanced.Highly recommended.

CommentsTitle: When it doesnt have issues its great
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 6, 2020
CommentsContent: I have always enjoyed the elite controllers for the tactile feel and overall design, Elite series 1 was a fantastic controller that unfortunately just was released right before xbox had changed their bluetooth connectivity method. So when Elite series 2 came out I was more than excited to start using it.When the controller is not having issues it is great, it feels good in the hand and the customization options continue the trend to personalize how you play a game. However there are major issues I have found and have been a result within the community you should be aware of: (these are the ones I had experienced)- Sometimes the controller seems to on its own have your screen list lazily to the side. There is some fundamentally issue with how the right joy stick is implemented that seems to make this happen. You dont always notice it unless you stop moving and leave it for a few seconds.- I have had a few times where the controller seems to come apart at the seam. This was a bigger issue for me. I would come up to the controller and for some reason the buttons were sort of falling in and the seem had opened. I was able to push down on it to reseal it but this was a bit odd given I dont drop or toss my controllers.So summary is, if you want a nice feeling controller with customization options but dont mind some of these oddities this can work great. However I do not think it is required if you are okay with your current setup, the price point is a bit extreme given the problems being found with it.

CommentsTitle: May be a lemon of a controller
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Update to below review.I returned the original control.  Amazon was extremely fast at getting me a replacement and made it very easy to return the replaced controller.  Unfortunately, that is about the only good thing I have to say.  The replacement controller worked great, but within days minor drift was detected on the left stick.  20 days in and the drift is so bad the controller hardly useable.  The left stick is either unresponsive or drifting.End of Update------------2 stars because the feel of the controller is outstanding, but the operability is bad.I have had this controller for about 1.5 months, and it has been my primary controller for that time (since launch).  The controller feels great.  It has a great weight to it.  The interchanging parts work well depending on play style.  That being said, the left stick drifts horribly.  It is bad enough for me to write this review.  In some games the drift will even cause menu changes.  I have found it to be unusable in games such as the Mass Effect series because the drift causes serious issues in menu mode.  In other games (such as Borderlands 3) the character continues to walk forward or back after I release the thumb stick.  I then have to pull back or forward / adjust on the stick to try to get my character to stand still.  I have not had the controller long enough to check if it has the issues with the previous elite series controller (which I went through three of them, two broke) such as the rubber separating from the plastic or the bumper buttons breaking down.  This controller is very much overpriced for the quality of the product in my opinion.  I purchased this controller hoping that the issues from the series one controller were fixed, but seemingly out of the box I have had the drift issue.  I have not yet contacted support but will update depending on how that conversation goes.  I recommend against this controller at this point in time, but also understand I may have a lemon.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 7, 2020
CommentsContent: I've used an original elite controller for a couple years, and while I haven't really had any issues myself, I have heard second-hand of people having issues. Now with the series 2, I started seeing an issue where it would randomly lose the wireless connection to the Xbox and the Xbox would pop up a message: "please reconnect the controller". The controller stays on the whole time, but after holding down/pressing down the guide button, it'll re-pair/sync after a few moments. Terrible when it happens mid-game/mid-fight. I wanted to get repaired under warranty after 3-4 months after buying it, but that was around feb/march and didn't think/want to bother support with this sort of thing then. So I waited a little longer but then happened to check the warranty: for some reason I thought it was (at least) 1 year, like almost all higher end electronic items I'm familiar with, but then I thought I found out it was only 6 months and mine was over that already anyway. On top of that, it looks like it might be 90 days now too, which is so ridiculous, I don't even know what to say.Microsoft, you had a history of elite 1 controllers breaking, you then carried this trend (and maybe even worse) to the elite 2, AND we only have 90 day warranty now on a $180+ premium controller? I feel cheated to say the least

CommentsTitle: Amazing improves gameplayts stick driftneeds to get repaired after a Welles of play
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 24, 2020
CommentsContent: So I’ll start saying I love the controller it definitely improved gameplay. However this would be a 5 star review if it worked properly after minimal use I’ll explain. Got the controller and for probably 1-2 days there was a learning experience curve between games and adjustments and settings probably about 6 hours of game time in total per game. So for multiple games definitely a time investment but between the games definitely worth it especially higher paced competitive games. My low review comes from I had the absolute worst stick drift Iv ever experienced with a controller and stick drift is why I decided to finally buy a high end controller. Microsoft is replacing my controller but it’s been 3 weeks and they just shipped it out to me with a 2 week wait time for shipping. Because Iv already passed my learning curve for the games I play COD rocket league Forza and PUBG. I don’t play them because I don’t want to deal with The readjustment time.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 19, 2020
CommentsContent: A definite improvement on the series 1. The wrap around grip feels great in your hand. The paddles are shorter than the series 1 so they give you more space to grip the controller. Or, if you are like me and you don’t use your fingers to hold the controller, you can buy series 1 paddles which are easier to reach. They will fit the series 2 perfectly. I was concerned that the tall stick was too tall and spent a while looking for a medium stick, but it turns out the tall stick is easy to get used to. I would encourage everyone to at least give it a try. It does seem expensive, but it is a huge improvement over the standard controller. Definitely worth the price if you spend a decent amount of time holding a controller.

CommentsTitle: Button presses fail to register, right out of the box
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 15, 2020
CommentsContent: I ordered this controller because I have osteoarthritis in my hands and the hair trigger switches allow me to pull the triggers much easier, without having full range of motion in my index fingers.  The four additional paddles on the underside of the controller also give me options for remapping buttons that I have a hard time pressing.  I was really looking forward to this controller for these reasons.Unfortunately, all of that functionality is completely negated by the fact that buttons on the face of the controller, particularly the A button, intermittently fail to register when pressed.  I'm not sure how you can call this an "elite" controller, when it can't even do what my 25-year-old antique Nintendo controller can still do, which is register a simple button press consistently.After a little researching, this appears to be a common issue with poor build quality and there are many reports of buttons not registering and other issues.  If this were a $30-$40 controller, I'd cut Microsoft some slack.  However, it's a $180 "premium" gaming accessory and this kind of issue just isn't acceptable, especially right out of the box.UPDATE #1:The longer I have this controller, the more issues I am finding.  Some buttons are registering double presses on a single press.  In addition, the controller doesn't work properly via Bluetooth.  When I first hooked it up, pressing the A button while connected via Bluetooth would adjust my volume and press F12 (at the same time).  I updated the firmware, which seemed to fix that issue.  However, pressing RB in game causes the display output to temporarily freeze up.  If you intend to use this via your PC's built in Bluetooth, or a non-Xbox adapter, you may be sorely disappointed.UPDATE #2:  Received a replacement and it's defective as well, with several buttons that stick or don't register when pressed.  Might even be more defective than the first one.  The level of quality control on these is pathetic.  Microsoft should honestly be ashamed.  At this point, I don't know if I just keep requesting replacements until I get one that works, or give up and find another controller solution.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 10, 2021
CommentsContent: I used to buy Scuff controllers because I loved having my buttons on the bottom of my controller.  I finally pulled the trigger and I was really surprised how much I liked this controller. The hair line triggers are great and I think my favorite part would be the option to tune the sticks. I have them tightened and the controller almost feels like the Xbox 360 sticks. Absolutely love the customization ability of this as well. You can also set up multiple profiles so you can switch between games without skipping a beat. I used this on my Xbox Series X, mostly for Halo and COD.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 7, 2020
CommentsContent: I really want to like the new XBox Elite Series 2 controller but it doesn’t seem to be much improved over the original Elite controllers. They increased the price over the original Series 1 but it doesn’t seem that they improved the joystick micro switches at all. The left joystick has already started experiencing stick drift within the first few weeks and the A and B buttons sometimes seem to miss registering that they’ve been pressed. On the plus side, XBox seems to have improved the LB and RB bumpers and the controller has a very quality feel and weight to it. Wireless recharging and the internal battery pack are an added plus but everything is soured by the problem with stick drift at such an early stage of ownership. I wish XBox would’ve done more testing to fix the problem.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 7, 2020
CommentsContent: I really wanted this go around to be better. I loved my original elite controller but like everyone else the bumpers failed just after the short 3 month warranty expired. So how does the elite v2 do? It is a marginal improvement in every way except now they are plagued with unresponsive button presses. Right out of the box I noticed my "B" button wasn't perfect, it had to be pressed more firmly to register or it would think I was rapidly tapping it. Annoying for a $160 controller, but not a deal breaker. Then, just a week after the pathetic (and red flag) 3 month warranty, the right bumper stops registering presses unless I hit it firmly. Using the accessory app to test, even firm presses are registering as quick rapid taps which shows something is breaking down internally. A complete redesign of the bumpers in v2 and they STILL fail.In Short: Another failure by Microsoft. Don't get me wrong, if this controller was built well it would be the best one out there bar none. However, MS or their manufacturer (or both) are cutting corners somewhere for a "premium" item and their lack of a meaningful warranty shows they are well aware of it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 25, 2021
CommentsContent: These controllers are fantastic when they work, the problem is they don't work for very long. I've had 2 of them already, and both of them developed severe problems with the left stick that make it very difficult to play the games I want to play. Every Xbox controller I've had for several years has developed a drift in the left stick, but these Elite 2 controllers are even worse. Not only do they drift, but they become unresponsive. Push it up and doesn't go up. It's frustrating. These controllers are way better than normal ones, but yet they're so much worse once the left stick stops working properly. Don't want to go back to normal controllers, but also don't want to keep buying one of these every 6 months. Tough choice.

CommentsTitle: Was really good then at day 100 not so much.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 23, 2020
CommentsContent: I liked the feel of the controller, the tensions settings were great.  The paddles are easier to use than my SCUF elite kit on the Series one controller.  I really had no complaints for the first two months or so.  The the RB button would work intermittently, and it would lose connection every so often.  Then it would not stay connected no matter what.  Would show full charge but would disconnect every 5 minutes and turn off.  Checked on warranty status and I had owned it 100 days.  of course the warranty is only 90.  Instead of being out 180 bucks I have to leave it plugged into a phone charger and I have the RB button mapped to a paddle.  Oh yeah, almost forgot one of the paddles doesn't work either.90 days is hardly enough time for problems to arise, the warranty is a joke.  Had the warranty been 1 year and it got fixed/replaced, I would chalk it up to my luck getting a dud controller.  The fact that it is only 90 days, they know problems will arise and they don't want to be on the hook.

CommentsTitle: Sturdy but doesn't come with much to customize with.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 28, 2020
CommentsContent: It's a heavy, solid controller that feels good in the hands and has magnetically attached joysticks D-pad, and paddle buttons underneath.The triggers both have 3 mechanical settings for depth of depression.My only real gripe is that the package wasn't complete. Or at least I don't feel it was for the price point.It only came with one set of the interchangeable buttons. So ontop of paying $160 or so I'd have to pay more if I wanted different buttons...I just don't see why the buttons aren't already included in the package I mean they Realistically shouldn't cost more than a nickel each to manufacture and purchase at wholesale b2b pricing.

CommentsTitle: Great controller, not really a huge improvement from the first series.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 2, 2019
CommentsContent: This controller is absolutely fantastic. The feel is grippier than the first controller. A built-in battery and charger makes it much easier to use and store. The new paddles have more friction to them and are easier to place your finger on.Thing is - it's not a huge improvement over the first series controller. I actually prefer the heft of the older controller. I have both right now - my girlfriend is using the series 1 and loves it - and I like both controllers for slightly different reasons.Great controller, but definitely not necessary if you have the first one.

CommentsTitle: UPDATE AT THE BOTTOM. Non responsive
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 30, 2020
CommentsContent: **4 MONTH UPDATE AT THE BOTTOM:**Tbh not really worth the price. It would be more worth it if it were about $120. The back paddles feel squishy after a while, if you drop your controller the attachments go flying everywhere, if you like playing wired, the wire is obnoxiously long and even if you want to use another wire its not the same as the regular xbox controllers. But overall its a better price than the scuf. For a maxed out scuf its about twice as much as the elite 2 and the elite 2 already has what a maxed out scuf has.*UPDATE*The left bumper on the controller is non responsive which is a COMMON problem for either bumper and microsoft still doesnt do anything about it. I only spent 4 months using it and barely even use the left bumper for it to just be nonresponsive. This controller is 100% not worth its price. Its just a normal controller given extra of the same buttons harder case and a few features. If you're going to buy this controller without warranty honestly its not even worth it. Especially if you're an advanced player. The left bumper is non responsive, the silicone/rubber covers on the trigger stopper switches fall off easily, and the paddles feel mushy instead of clicky after a while. Amazon couldnt do anything about it. I tried to send it back to get a replacement which would be fair right? No. They said they couldnt do anything about it. Bought it may and return expired june. Not much time for something to not work correctly anymore. I would have no problem sending in my controller and getting ATLEAST a refurbished one.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 7, 2020
CommentsContent: After a few months of very infrequent use, the A button has become unresponsive to a normal press and only responds to a hard press.What's worse is I contacted microsoft, and based on the controller's "activation date" I was not eligible for a replacement. I purchased this controller less than 6 months before I had the issue and submitted a request for replacement.Buying a $150+ controller and having it break down 6 months later with no option for a replacement or repair is very disappointing. I will not be recommending this to anyone, and I surely will not buy another microsoft xbox product for my PC again unless it's a cheap replaceable thing.

CommentsTitle: Absolutely not worth it, problems out of the box
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 18, 2020
CommentsContent: Bought mine as a pre-order and right out of the box the triggers had issues. Unlike any other product you might buy, there's no support or fixes from Microsoft. I was hoping the trigger issue (wouldn't recognize triggers on the shortest pull setting) would be fixed with an update, but then the drift and erratic direction controls made the controller totally unusable. As a casual gamer, my total time using the controller could be measured in hours, not days, months or years. For the money, it's an absolute slap in the face from Microsoft and after almost 20 years of supporting Xbox, I think this year I'm going to switch platforms.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2020
CommentsContent: I know it’s pricey. But how often do you buy a controller. I still have my elite series one controller. The rubber pads were coming off. But I love that controller. I’ll glue the pads back on. But the elites series controller improves on the first one. Lighter weight the gripes are better. You can tell they won’t come off this time. It has a share button and a internal battery. The internal batter is the only thing I don’t like. Because what do you do when it doesn’t hold a charge properly. You have to then plug it in with the cable. I don’t know if you can send it in to have the battery replaced. If not then it’s a new controller which is a waste of money. But right now it’s a great controller easy to grip won’t fall out your hands and responsive.

CommentsTitle: 2 months old and has STICK DRIFT already
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 15, 2020
CommentsContent: Un-effin-believable! Less than 2 months old and already stick drift. Had 3 previous Elite controllers (Gen 1) and each had bumpers break and wicked stick drift after about 6 months (did not buy them all, 2 were gifts). Now, after all the Microsoft hype about more sturdy parts, craftsmanship, etc. my new Gen 2 already has stick drift. How hard can it be not to use garbage parts in those Chinese sweat-shops? Google has started to fill-up with stick drift complaints and these haven't been out but a couple of months... Never again.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2020
CommentsContent: I’ve now owned this controller for 8 months now and it has not broken or given me any of the reported problems.I will say this though, the controller is heavy around the grips and uncomfortable to play with unless you hold it at an angle titled down.Basically, it will have your palms feeling like you are doing a weird palm workout.

CommentsTitle: Overall great build quality, bad face buttons, bad software
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 1, 2020
CommentsContent: This controller's build quality is generally excellent.Pros:* The analog sticks have variable resistance that is stiff near the center for precise control, but looser toward the edges which makes them easier to hold in place at full tilt.* The beveled d-pad has faces in the corners which make pressing the diagonals reliably a cinch - no doubt a boon for fighting games.* Of the controllers with paddles I've owned (PowerA Fusion, Razer Wolverine Ultimate, and I guess the Steam controller), the Elite Series 2 has just about the best - they're small enough that they don't get in the way or make your grip less comfortable, but are placed so you can hit them quickly no problem. They -can- fall out by accident, but not often or easily.* Has the best adjustable-depth triggers on any controller I've used. At all depth settings they have a springy bump when you bottom out that gives positive tactile feedback: something other controllers I've tried lack.* Ergonomics are pretty good - the grip is comfortable and the controller doesn't weigh too much.Cons:* The face buttons (X, Y, A, B) are the same as the stock Xbox One's wireless controller's, and on mine they were appreciably worse. They would sometimes stick and also wouldn't pick up light/quick presses reliably, which is a problem I've yet to have on any other controller.* On PC, the Elite Series 2 -requires- you to create or sign in to a Microsoft account to program the paddles or adjust any other settings. When you sign in to use the app, it also signs you in to every Microsoft service present on Windows. Personally, I just want to program the hardware I bought and own, not volunteer myself as a donor of personal data to Michaelsoft's me-too attempt at surveillance capitalism.The cons make the controller a no go for me. Save for not being wireless, the Razer Wolverine Ultimate is, in my opinion, comparable to or better than the Elite Series 2 in every way. Razer's controller software doesn't require a login to use, you can program paddles directly on the controller without it, and it has two extra paddles on the shoulders.

CommentsTitle: At least I don't have stick drift...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 9, 2020
CommentsContent: For a premium price, you expect a premium product.  At first glance, you think you're getting that.  The controller has good heft and all the components feel like high-quality parts.But that's where the good news ends.  Here are all the issues my controller encountered.1. The right trigger (RT) started to have a weird click when bottoming out.  Whereas the left trigger is still soft like it was on day 1.  This problem started happening probably a week after light use.2. The A button doesn't register sometimes.  It seems to be based on the angle where I press the button but this same issue has never occurred on my regular Xbox One controllers.3. The right bumper (RB) will frequently register a double-click and cause multiple inputs even when I physically only feel one click.I see lots of complaints about stick drift but fortunately I have not experienced this.The A button issue was present from day 1.  The RT trigger issue cropped up probably around the 50 hour usage mark.  I don't know when the RB issue started happening but I only recently noticed it due to a game I recently started playing that was sensitive to double-inputs.The worst part is I didn't really use the controller heavily enough to realize how intolerable all these stacked issues were until I was outside the short 90-day warranty period to get a replacement.  So now I'm stuck with a controller that I would hardly call "Elite" or gives me a good gaming experience.

CommentsTitle: Does not fix series 1 issues - defective straight from box
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 3, 2020
CommentsContent: Have a series 1, it has stick drift and the bumper button is broke. Bought this series 2, straight from the box the "A" button sticks, and also the right joystick drifts towards the left, and there was some white powder stuff on the grips. It was brand new, sealed.Did not receive 2 of the "long" joysticks like the series 1, it only came with 1 long joystick. I tried to put the long joysticks from the series 1 onto the series 2, they are not compatible - go figure.I read that this controller was supposed to be better for big hands, this is not the case. I have to grip the controller completely differently, lower on the grips with my pinky fingers not even touching anything. My hands were actually sore from holding this controller, I haven't had sore hands like this since the original NES with the sharp corners... If I hold the controller comfortably, then I cannot use any of the rear buttons (they will just be smashed). I have to grip the controller using my palms, with my fingers floating over the buttons (hold your hand as if you are talking with a sock puppet, this is how I have to grip the controller). IMO If I can't use the rear buttons then there is no reason to own this controller.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 20, 2020
CommentsContent: This is the only controller I use for playing on Xbox or PC. The series 2 is certainly an improvement over the original Elite controller. It's still as durable as its predecessor with a few more features.  -The old micro-USB port which broke easily is replaced by the more durable USB-C port.  -The grips now look to be part of the frame rather than glued on.  -The hair triggers have a mid-option for more fine tuning.  -The battery is now built-in, which lasts quite a while. I keep the controller plugged in by USB so I don't really need to recharge it.Overall I'm very satisfied and someday I may buy another for the Xbox as a backup and so I don't need to keep re-pairing it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2020
CommentsContent: Very nice controller, fits in my hands perfect.When I first got this controller my greatest fear was realized - one of the buttons stuck. However, after using a q-tip and some rubbing alcohol AND working in the button - it worked and still works as it should.I used to use the razor wolverine Xbox one controller but wanted to opt to a wireless controller. Although it has 2 less “extra buttons” than the wolverine, it’s not as clunky. The paddles are easier to use albeit a little hard to get used to after using a different controller for so long, but now it’s second nature.I love love love the imbedded, rechargeable battery that comes in the controller. I don’t have to buy double A’s anymore I just lay in on it’s charger after I get done playing and it’s ready to go and fully charged the next time I play. It’s never ran out of juice for me yet but I don’t play more than 4-5 hours at a time. The battery is suppose to last 40 hours of continuous gameplay fully charged, which is crazy awesome!The grips are nice, the feel of the controller is comfortable.One of my favorite parts is the ability to change ANY of the buttons to ANY button of your choosing. Makes some games more familiar with other ones, and easier to learn and play.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 10, 2019
CommentsContent: I think everyone who buys this goes to the same self doubt that I did before actually pulling the trigger and making this purchase. The bottom line is this controller will hands-down change the way you play games and all for the better. If you really are into gaming you will find this will improve your game play in all manners of ways. Personally I use it for everything now from getting a slight edge in dark souls two fun open world games like red dead redemption or Jedi fall on order. The configuration options are endless and the paddles are extremely useful. Paddles and stick tension aside this controller feels great. It’s got excellent weight and has a nice rubberized feel. I highly recommend this for adult gamers especially the ones that really care about their hobby

CommentsTitle: So good, It's almost like cheating.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2021
CommentsContent: First time buying a "pro" controller here. I've been skeptical about spending so much money on a video controller, but I think it's fairly justifiable. It's every bit as hyped and I can really feel the improvement of my aiming over my stock Series X controller. But is it a necessity? Probably depends on how serious you are about wanting to up your game.The dinged a star because the A button is kinda sticky... I've read some reports and unfortunately it's an issue for me as well right off the box. I'm going to see if I can do some simple remedy or if the problem would go away on its own before I request an exchange.

CommentsTitle: Don't even think about buying this item. Terrible product quality.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 15, 2020
CommentsContent: This is the last time I ever buy a control from xbox. You're paying close to $200 for a great quality product right? Nope! Right out of the box I've had problems pressing the A button. Then, shortly after, the left stick started to drift. Now about 4 months later it is absolutely  unbearable. The right bumper is so broken that I had to use one of the paddles for it. Another thing, for games where you have to hold A to sprint, or hold a button or mash a button, the paddles are ridiculously unresponsive. All in all this product really had me very disapointed. It looks and feels premium, but the original control that I have has better components. A very disapointing, expenssive waist of money.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 5, 2020
CommentsContent: This is the best controller that I’ve ever held, and ever heard of hands down. I originally got a trial controller that I busted fairly quickly because of my own stupidity. Slamming the controller down and walking away to cool off was just enough to dislocate the left analog stick beyond repair. After this purchase, I’m a lot more cautious and after having used this controller for a total of about a year now, I can definitely say it’s a quality premium controller. If you’re prone to rage during your gaming sessions you’ll want to be able to think before you act with this controller because it is fragile. The grips are satisfyingly comfy, the dpad is metal which makes every click enjoyable, the bumpers are not metal even though they look like they are (imo they should be metal), I don’t use the analog stick sensitivity adjustment nor the trigger toggle but I can see how people would enjoy that feature, the manual customization through Xbox’s accessories app is AMAZING and I love being able to customize the vibration strength, aim sensitivity presets, Xbox logo LED strength, and the name for the controller itself. The interchangeable analog sticks is what really sold me on this controller. I actually find myself swapping analog sticks for different games to suit my comfort level, not because I need to but because it’s easy and makes a difference for me personally. Considering how long this controller has been out I’d actually advise you to look into the Elite Series 3 controller, depending on when you’re reading this. The only reason I say that is because of the change from the first Elite controller to the Elite Series 2 being a strong upgrade, I can’t even imagine what another upgraded version would look like. In summary, as long as you treat this controller like your baby, clean regularly, keep away from excessive moisture, and NEVER drop or throw this controller, it will satisfy most gamers.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2020
CommentsContent: Fantastic build quality, options, and utility.Pros: Battery life is good, though I use my plugged in almost always. The internal battery makes this heavier for me because I used the Elite series 1 plugged in with an empty battery bay, but the weight isn't too bad.Customization is great. Maybe too good for the average gamer, but the average gamed probably wouldn't drop over $100 for a controller. Microsoft includes options to completely re-map the controller, a 3-stage trigger lock, a 100 point trigger control (when to begin sensing a pull and when to reach 100%--highly recommend setting this to the point you've locked your trigger to, e.g. if you lock your trigger to 50% of a pull, tell it to consider a 50% pull as a 100% of a pull. In Destiny 2, for example, you'll never be able to drive your sparrow at full speed if you don't do this or deal with hitting the trigger switch every time you get on/off.)Custom joystick curves are amazing if you spend the time fine-tuning them, but you'll NEVER be able to use another controller again. Be warned.Cons: I don't enjoy that the paddles are significantly smaller on this version than the series 1. In fact, I use the 2 lower series 1 paddles on the series 2. Most people wouldn't have an issue with this, and it actually makes it easier to set your controller down on a soft material without accidentally pressing buttons, like putting your controller down on a couch cushion.Note: the bumpers have been changed for the newer, more durable version on this controller. I only had to replace mine once on my old one, but these even feel much more solid. As for the grip concern, I've never had an issue with any xb1 controller. I don't grip my controllers super firmly, or try to pull my controller in half when I lose a game, so they've never slid or peeled on any controller for me. These seem to be even better than the series 1 controller I own which had several thousand hours of play time on it and never came apart, but if you have noticed that you grip your controllers very hard, you may have issues.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2021
CommentsContent: Loving the different customization I can do.. first expensive controller had for couple days now.. long gaming sessions the only complaint I feel like my hands get sweater but not a huge deal.. the above pictures is what I'm doing until I get use to the paddles.  The controller reviews claim have durability issues but it comes with warranty so idk haven't had long enough to comment on that tho***** what 3 week update*****Stick drift occurred very badly brand new so changed from 5 stars to 1 because at $180 you would think it last way longer (due to durability ) but it was definitely an awesome controller

CommentsTitle: DEFECTIVE DO NOT BUY. March 1st 2021 still defective
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 30, 2020
CommentsContent: All Elite Series 2 controllers are defective. I had to send this controller back to microsoft for a replacement. Today I stopped at gamestop, they told me everyone js returning them, for turning off. Randomly

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 2, 2021
CommentsContent: This is the best controller I’ve ever own by a large margin. The battery life is incredible, you can remap any of the buttons to the back paddles, you can adjust all sorts of responses both digital and tactile, you can swap joysticks and pads, the materials are comfortable and premium. It’s just all very well designed and thought out. I do have a single problem: if I connect via usb, I have to forget the Bluetooth connection and repair the controller to get it working wirelessly again. That’s the only issue. 5/5 definitely worth the high price.

CommentsTitle: Left thumbstick drifts after 5mo of use. Warranty expired 3 months after purchase. DO NOT BUY!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 4, 2020
CommentsContent: I started out really enjoying this controller, even though I originally felt the somewhat unresponsive face buttons that others have reported.After 5 months of use, the left thumbstick is now drifting and appears to be getting worse daily. This is fairly unacceptable for a supposed "Elite" controller that was nearly $200.  In addition to the hardware issues, MS only supported this controller for 3 months after purchase, even though Amazon is an "Authorized Retailer". Their support site mentions a way to "extend the warranty" however there is no direct link to do this.  My only option is to pay MS another $99 for them to send me a replacement.I do not recommend getting this controller.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 6, 2019
CommentsContent: I just got the controller today and have used it for a few hours now playing Modern Warfare. Controller is great, superb build quality, even more customization than the first Elite controller and has some great new features. One can now have 3 custom profiles plus one more if you include the default preset, one can even map not just buttons to the paddles but functions such as recording clips and one can even adjust the tension of each joystick. I have to say Microsoft has outdone themselves and have went beyond what the first Elite had to offer in every way, which I have had since its launch 4 years ago, and is truly one of if not the best controller one can buy. Highly recommend.

CommentsTitle: A solid well built controller with features making it worthy of the price.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2020
CommentsContent: Casual gaming on PC.  Better feel and responsiveness than the standard Xbox controller.  Mind you, the standard controller is very well made in my opinion, and replacements for the wear parts are readily available online.  The battery has not let me down and I do appreciate the included charger which nests inside the case allowing you to charge while storing the controller.  The adjustability is excellent.  Do note that you must use the PC Xbox accessory app to adjust the majority of the settings.  The X, Y, A, and B buttons would fail to register on occasion (very annoying for FPS) when the controller was brand new.  This diminished after a few gaming sessions and I have not seen the problem return in months, not once.  For reference I purchased before release.  I did install a firmware update right out of the box, before using the controller.  The overall quality of materials, fit, and finish is excellent.  It has a solid well built feel that is a tad on the heavy side, but very manageable.  I generally take very good care of my electronics, and there are no noticeable signs of wear at this time several months into ownership with moderate use.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 7, 2019
CommentsContent: This is a mighty upgrade from the first elite controller, the best thing Microsoft added is the Type-C charger with the docking port. It's just so useful now. The quality feels great and well made. There is a drastic difference between the normal Xbox controller to this one. I'm just a typical gamer, but oh-boy, this screams premium all over. I just owned it for 2 days and so far I just can't find any cons to it. The built-in battery might be an issue down the road, but I don't think that will be a huge problem for at least a few years. By then, you'll probably be using a series 3. Microsoft has said it will be compatible with the next-generation consoles, so that's a bonus.And also did I mention this controller can now be charged from inside the box holder?

CommentsTitle: A, B, X, Y may not respond
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 22, 2020
CommentsContent: So I have been using this controller for a week now. I have played Apex, COD, and Overwatch using this controller, each having their own settings. The paddles are nice, even though I did purchase a set from the older Elite Series 1 just so I can have four long paddles instead of the short ones (it just works better for my fingers). However, my main and only real complaint is....the main buttons A, B, X, Y they all either stick or don't respond to the touch. This has gotten me killed a couple of times since I am not fully used to using my paddles yet. I don't know if this is a software or hardware issue but I know I am not the only one who has had this issue.Other then that, this paddle is great.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 18, 2020
CommentsContent: This controller has made me never want to buy or use a different controller. I play from PC now, and primarily use this controller for RPGs, like Assassin's Creed and other similar games. It's comfortable, has a reassuring weight, and the triggers have completely changed how I play. I highly recommend this controller to anyone, as I fully think it is worth the high price. I did not experience any of the issues experiences by other customers, such as sticky buttons or any wear and tear after a couple of months of use.Update: After a couple hundred hours of use, this controller is still working terrifically. I have zero complaints, and still can't consider ever using a different controller again.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 26, 2020
CommentsContent: So like many others are writing I too got a defective one where the A button requires a hard push in order to register which is unacceptable. There is no reason that Microsoft should be having any of these kind of quality issues especially with a top of the line $180 controller. My guess is they pumped these controllers out without any testing to verify that they are in working order. Don't get me wrong, these controllers are actually amazing in terms of build and feel, I actually do prefer it over my elite 1 but it cannot have defective buttons.. I'll take the crappier older version with buttons that work 100% of the time over a newer model with an A button that only registers 50% of the time.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 25, 2020
CommentsContent: This controller costs too much money for every button activation to not register precisely every time. I bought this for my son in early July 2020 and already end of August 2020, the LB button misses activations or double activates (registers as two clicks). He is very careful with it and has always stored it in the case it came with. He’d be happier with $180 of AA batteries. Google this problem before ordering, you’ll see plenty of other people have a similar issue.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 13, 2020
CommentsContent: Easily the best Xbox controller ever.You can immediately feel the quality of it when handling it. I use it exclusively on PC, and it works perfectly anywhere an Xbox controller works. The spider leg things are nifty, but I haven't been able to figure out how to really make the best use of them. I got the Microsoft program that lets you basically map the other controller buttons to it, but I would ideally like to map keyboard buttons to it. I haven't really dug into it very much, but I imagine that may not work too well since games are usually controller or keyboard and mouse, and not a mashup of the two, so the game itself may act oddly.I am quite careful with my electronics, but I could imagine a lot of people losing those little spider leg paddles if they aren't careful.Between this and my steam controller, I rarely have to switch to a dedicated keyboard and mouse unless I want to.

CommentsTitle: I Wished the Reviews Weren't True
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 19, 2020
CommentsContent: I tried really hard to justify this purchase. I loved the interchangeable thumbsticks, the rear paddles, and all the other nifty things that came along with this controller. I wished the low score reviews weren't true.But they were. The "A" button was sticky and the left bumper was loose. One thing I didn't expect was how heavy the controller was. Also, while the rubber grips are a great touch, your hands get pretty warm (sweaty) after holding the controller for a lengthy period of time.They advertised improvements over the 1st gen Elite controllers. This feels just as bad.Already returned.

CommentsTitle: ALL OF THESE ARE BROKEN, KNOWN FAULTY HARDWARE ISSUE! DO NOT BUY!!!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 2, 2020
CommentsContent: You pay the extra money to not deal with issues and all i have ever had with this thing is issues.  Yeah the packaging is nice.  Yeah the feel is nice.  But for what its supposed to actually do and be, a premium controller, it is not.  They should have spent more money the actual main controller components instead of the look and feel of the thing.First off, the buttons stick.  Everyone I have tested right out of the box the buttons stick.  You roll from one button to the other? One button is going to get stuck down.  Its not a bad batch...its all of them, and if you got one that isnt stick that much then you got one that was used.  Q-tip with some rubbing alcohol on the buttons helped a little with that issue.2nd issue, and the biggest issue of them all right now...the LB and RB buttons double click.  this isnt a patch or a firmware issue.  this isnt a take apart and clean issue.  the buttons themselves are faulty and have to be replaced.  They are completely unreliable and useless on the controller and no fix at all for them.  Complete waste of money.Some other issues, all the sticks on them wobble which means you cant have a low deadzone without having "drift".  Fine for most users, but none of the pro users are going to like it at all.  Yeah increase the deadzone but seriously THIS IS SUPPOSED TO BE A PRO CONTROLLER NOT A CHEAP 20 DOLLAR CONTROLLER.  Like I said, looks and feels good but doesnt do at all what its supposed to.

CommentsTitle: This is great for PC! (Well, it was for a couple months...)
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 7, 2020
CommentsContent: Edit: After having it for awhile I have to reduce the rating to 1 stars.  The buttons stick randomly and the bumpers and triggers will just randomly not work. Great concept and an improvement over the original but functionality is a problem.Three things...1. The software to setup profiles on Windows is nice. Setup is easy and switching profiles is simple. Trouble can happen if the game you play has internal settings for Xbox (I have to leave “Xbox controller support” OFF in Steam).2. It is a bit heavy. If you like that or not, it is what it is.3.  The battery is rechargeable and INTERNAL (not replaceable). It comes with the charging “stand” that is a really small, LIGHTWEIGHT base. I mention this as a warning as it can stay attached (magnetically I think) to the controller, and fall after you lift the controller. This is my only reason for it not getting 5 stars from me.GG

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 17, 2020
CommentsContent: Never buying an elite controller again. Bought the series 2 controller when it first came out, was great at first but after about 6 months the right bumper started to become unresponsive. ( I would have to hit the bumper about 3 times to get it to finally work.) Then after about another 6 months the right stick click stopped working. For those who play FPS no more melee..So I made the mistake of buying a brand new elite controller. Again, worked great at the start and after about 6 months the right bumper again became unresponsive.The xbox elite series 2 controller is by far the worst controller I've ever used. I initially bought it to replace my elite series one controller ( that worked perfectly fine, even added custom bumpers, grips and faceplate.) And now I'm dusting off my old series one and using that again because the series 2 has failed me yet again.

CommentsTitle: Great until left stick drift defect.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 24, 2020
CommentsContent: The controller’s customization is awesome and the possibilities are endless. I can see how it can give you an edge across different genres. So I was in love, For about 4 weeks.. then I started noticing consistent left stick drift. I tried resetting profiles, updating the controller, using it plugged in but Nothing fixed it.Worse then that, if the controller is left untouched for a minute or two, the d-pad freaks out until you move the left stick.Microsoft is willing to exchange but I’ll be waiting 10-14 days for a replacement which hopefully doesn’t have the same issues. For $180 the headache isn't worth it. Apparently the drift issue is way too common.  I’ve been super careful with the controller and still I ended up with a defective controller.If the issue started during the return period I’d definitely just return it and keep using my regular Xbox controller.Hopefully you all have a better experience.

CommentsTitle: A DETAILED REVIEW ON THE CONTROLLER
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 14, 2021
CommentsContent: This controller is a game changer. I mean that literally.Packaged took about 6 days to ship, fairly quick shipping. It was handled with care.I primarily play FPS games like COD and APEX Legends, and I bought this controller hoping for its quicker draw and fire times (hair triggers) for quick scoping and for its customizable stick sensitivity. Well, I got it set up (nothing special was needed, I connected it like any other controller with the Bluetooth) and got on COD. I was absolute dog water all day using the controller. I had adjusted the settings on the sticks and the hair triggers to be more sensitive than my original controller, but only by about 30%, so that I could still play without it feeling completely foreign. After another 2 days playing with the same settings I’m cracked again. It just took some getting used to. Overall, I believe this controller has improved my gameplay by quite a bit. My stats have gone up over the last week, even after the first 2-3 days of getting wrecked while getting used to the new settings. On another note, the rechargeable battery is very convenient. To Xbox gamers who play everyday for extended periods of time, like myself, we all know how expensive it is to be buying batteries every other week, or how annoying it is to put your rechargeable battery’s in the charger every night. All I’ve got to do with this is just set it on its stand when I’m done and it charges. They claim 40 hours of battery life, and I believe it. I played with the controller for 11 hours straight yesterday (I admit with some shame) and the controller battery icon on the Home Screen said full. Neat. Lots of people in the reviews complain about having sticky keys or sticks, haven’t noticed any of that. The A key seems to need a firm press, but I got used to it pretty quickly. So, to wrap this up, is this worth $250? Yeah it is. Stop thinking about it just buy it, maybe if you do I won’t make your K/D go negative next time you’re in my lobby.

CommentsTitle: I wish I'd have just bought another series 1 elite
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 14, 2020
CommentsContent: I hate this controller.  I loved my series 1. In fact so much that I was willing to buy replacement bumpers and eventually replaced the controller itself 3x because nothing compared.  This controller however sucks. The abxy  buttons (mostly b and y) stick relentlessly despite being completely clean. The charge built in last awhile but its so annoying to not be able to plug in a charger while I play.  I wish I would've just bought a 4th series 1 and never wasted money on this. Its a step in the wrong direction Microsoft. It just makes me sad.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 24, 2020
CommentsContent: Pros: Shipping was quick and on time. The controller itself is outstanding. Superb build quality, great ergonomics, customizable. I really enjoy the controller.Cons: First and foremost, there are to buying options that were available at the time I purchased. $165 for a used (great condition) or $205 new. I opted for the new. The controller delivered was a used product. The factory seal on the controller box itself was cut open. The controller had already been "customized" (buttons can be swapped), a few very minor blemishes and the controller had a bug that when you pressed the "A" Button (aka button 2) the controller also pressed the "Xbox" button (aka button 13). I assume that's why this unit was probably returned. Since I purchased new but received a used device I took away 2 stars. I took another star away because the controller appears to have had an issue, and was shipped with that same issue.Notes: The fix for the controller was a firmware update, which did require the Xbox accessory app from the Microsoft store. Once the updated controller worked beautifully and have had no issues so far. I will not, however, adjust the rating since the stars I removed were due to the reasons above.TL:DR Controller is amazing! Definitely recommended even at the price point it's at.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Like the headline says bought this when it was on sale and under the impression that the condition would be new. It wasn't and as a matter of fact it didn't even come in its original box. The other person still had settings attached to the controller when I paired it to my xbox. Besides my slight annoyance to that still stuck with the controller. The good news is that it feels great! Bad news is that after only having it for a few days I noticed the left stick was drifting. Seems this is still a problem with certain batches of controllers. If it weren't for the stick drift I would highly recommend this controller. Lucky I have two (second one was a gift) so this one that isn't working as well will just be used as a backup.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 26, 2020
CommentsContent: I have had 3 of these controllers, and each one has had major issues.  I have since decided to just return the last one and wash my hands of it.The first - Bluetooth issues, constantly disconnecting.  The d pad was completely loose, causing it to wobble requiring a much harder press on the left than the right.  I purchased this one at Best Buy.The second - same connectivity issues, and the left trigger would stick down returned to amazon.  (Amazing shipping btw)The third (a replacement from amazon) had already been opened, played with (looks like a lot) and was absolutely filthy. With white gunk under the lip of the joysticks, with all the accessories all over the place.  I’m assuming this one was another return that was just routed to me.  I didn’t plug it in to test due to the condition of it.The controller does feel great in the hands.  Weighty and solid.  But it seems to have major QC issues, that I never had with myFirst elite controller.Maybe I’ll get one down the road, but only at a retail location where I can take it out right there before I leave to inspect it.Too many issues surrounding this controller...

CommentsTitle: This controller would be 5/5 if it wasn't for the drifting joystick

CommentsContent: After 2 weeks the LT button started to stick.  Everytime I pressed down on the button it had resistance.  Then 2 weeks later the LB button started to stick. So holding the controller is more cumbersome.  I'd rather buy 3 of the original controllers than one of these hunk of metal pieces of junk.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 11, 2020
CommentsContent: Used my controller for about 5 months and was super happy with it. Feels nice, looks great. I am not accidentally not clicking it or accidentally clicking it twice. CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 25, 2020
CommentsContent: I previously had a Elite Series 1 and to be honest other then the extra grip on the front and the extra hair trigger option, there isnt much of a difference. But that's what makes it good. They improved on Series 1 controller quite a bit. One thing im glad about is that they made it usb-c. A issue I had with the series 1 and all xbox controllers in general was that micro usb is just such a bad cord... it breaks so easily. So im very happy about that change. Other then that you can't really go wrong here, Ive had it for 5 or 6 months now and I havent had any issues so far and still plays like brand new. Overall great controller, love it!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 10, 2020
CommentsContent: This controller worked great initially. Feels great to hold, nice and weighty, but not so much so that it is cumbersome. That said, this controller has become increasingly unresponsive. I have noticed inputs being delayed by up to a full second when running wirelessly. I started using the controller exclusively in wired mode and it cut the delay down to roughly half a second, but that is still way to much delay for any game that requires precise timing (looking at you Dead by Daylight and Dark Souls 3). I have also had tons of issues with the right bumper registering 2-3 inputs off of one push. I am very disappointed in this product as Xbox controllers are the most comfortable in my hands.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 10, 2020

I’d rank this as being a better buy than a 300lb burrito-crushing man buying baby powder on a hot day in an amusement park. CommentsTitle: Quality is not where it should be for a $180 controller.

CommentsContent: I have now gone through three of these, each one has had an issue with one of the face buttons being sticky or squishy right out of the box new. CommentsContent: Microsoft removed elite one series to force serious gamers to purchase the series two controller. CommentsTitle: It’s great, if you’re willing to spend a bit
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2020
CommentsContent: Great controller. It is rather expensive so some people might not want to buy it and that is understandable. If you have a working normal elite I would not upgrade. The only real differences I’ve noticed are the elite 2 having easier to use paddles (which I don’t use because it’s really hard to get used to), probably some hardware and durability upgrades, and an internal battery. If batteries are a problem, you could really just get rechargeable ones. They’re amazing.But. If you’re like me and you’re upgrading to the elite series two from a normal Xbox one controller or Xbox one s/x, then I’d say go for it. Normal controllers for me always get stick drift after a few months and they become unusable. I’ve had this one for only a little over a month but it’s really incredible compared to a normal controller. The new d pad isn’t crazy useful except for games where you can make really nice combos with it, and the internal battery actually lasts a while and is convenient to charge. I don’t use hair trigger locks or paddles a lot though. They just don’t help me very much. But it’s probably different for everyone.All in all, I would go for it if you currently are using a normal $60 Xbox controller. If you already have a perfectly working elite series one, however, I would just stick with that as there really aren’t huge differences. Hope this helps! Leave a comment if you have questions.

CommentsTitle: Looks great; doesn't work on PC
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 9, 2020
CommentsContent: It's so unfortunate that something that feels so great works so poorly. A simple Google search and you will see this controller has been plagued with issue. I took a chance hoping that Microsoft had patched the bluetooth issue and the 'A' button sticking was an early batch issue. It's not fixed. My 'A' button sticks so much I just had to use the paddles, a number of times in Fallen Order I died because Cal didn't jump when I pushed 'A' lol so that alone is enough to return it. Then there's the bluetooth issue. As many others have found, it's an issue with this controller. I updated drivers, windows, removed all other bluetooth devices, it didn't matter, this this would disconnect after playing for 5 minutes. I know this is a software/firmware issue, because if you connect the controller and don't do anything it will stay connected indefinitely. You also can't configure the controller over bluetooth, so you connect the cable, configure the controller, then it breaks the link. You have to remove the controller and re-sync it, every time.I wanted so badly to love it, and maybe it works well on Xbox (if you get an 'A' button that works) but if you're getting this for a PC save yourself time and money.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 6, 2019
CommentsContent: Pros:More profilesCan tighten the analog sticksCan activate triggers soonerProfiles register the triggers as full press with the other settinfsCons:Smaller back peddles (series 1 back peddles fit)Series 1 analog sticks don't fitOnly comes with 1 of the 2 different analog stick optionsDoesn't have as large of an analog stick optionInternel battery so if it fails you have to send it in for repairs instead of replacing the batteryAfter 1 year update:My a RB is less responsive. Fiance's LB broke right off. Microsoft seems to not be wanting to restock these and allow the scalpers to charge even more for these shoddy controllers. I'm done with Microsoft products.

CommentsTitle: Great remote!!! We will buy again
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought this elite 2 remote for my husband as a Christmas gift but he intercepted the Amazon box and opened it so he got a early Christmas gift. CommentsTitle: Does not work when another bluetooth device is in use
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 3, 2020
CommentsContent: I started out plesantly surprised by the feel of this controller and immediately began playing. I was completely happy for all of one hour until I turned on my headset and hopped into a chat with a buddy to discuss this controller. The elite series 2 controller immediately disconnected from bluetooth and attempted to reconnect, multiple times. This controller and from what I read via support forums all elite series 2 controllers have a glaring issue in that they do not work when another bluetooth device is being used on PC. This seems like a silly issue, considering a normal xbox one controller doesn't have this issue. This problem has existed since this controller has released with no fix.So to be clear, a simple but common use case of using bluetooth headphones and this controller simultaneously causes the controller to disconnect every 5 seconds and become completely unresponsive.To me, this is completely unacceptable and is pretty indicative of major problems with QA or long-term support for an expensive luxury product and I wouldn't recommend this controller even if your use case did not overlap with mine.

CommentsTitle: Great quality, some tradeoffs vs V1
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2019
CommentsContent: The most noticeable improvement is the joysticks and their adjustable sensitivity--its leagues better than V1. The controller is noticeably lighter. The build quality on the whole is better. The included charging cradle is an excellent addition.My only complaints: V2 is slightly smaller than V1 which is a pain for my large hands and they got rid of the grippy material on the handles. Now there is a "knurled" texture at the grips but it's the same plastic material as the rest of the controller. This material is not great for sweaty hands. Moisture stays on the surface of the controller and makes it feel slippery. The old grips absorbed some moisture and just felt "grippier."

CommentsTitle: Excellent successor to the Series 1 - an improvement in every way
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 25, 2020
CommentsContent: I used the Series 1 for several years and while a great controller, using the paddles was a bit difficult. They were a hair trigger and so it was quite easy to either miss inputs or enter inputs at the wrong time. The paddles on the Series 2 are much better designed and not nearly as sensitive. The built-in Bluetooth connectivity is also great and avoids the use of a secondary USB wireless adapter. Grip is comfortable and the overall weight of the controller is great - feels nice and light. The storage case and charging mount are sleek and easily fit into any gaming setup aesthetic.

CommentsTitle: Seemingly Fixed Issues of the First Generation, New Issues for Second Generation

CommentsContent: I haven't had any of the common issues that I and others experienced with the first Xbox Elite controller, but I purchased this in October of 2020 and it already has horrendous joystick drift constantly. CommentsTitle: Amazing controller, just one issue when it was shipped.

I prefer the smaller sized thumbsticks and I only recieved one in the box. Sucks. But I bought Kontrol freaks anyways. As a competitive player I prefer this over the version 1 elite and any other controller for xbox.

CommentsTitle: LEFT CONTROLLER JOYSTICK DRIFTS/DOESN'T READ MOVEMENT CORRECTLY. MICROSOFT WON'T HELP

Scuff or 3rd party will (unfortunately) be the replacement for this as well as the one I will be getting my wife.I would NOT recommend getting this controller without some sort of extended warranty. CommentsTitle: One of the most expensive piece of hardware that was waste of money

CommentsTitle: The controllers love to drift after a few months of usage and makes the any game unplayable

CommentsContent: For the price it’s just not worth it. This only lasted me about 6 months and now the left stick is drifting and it’s not registering  my movements anymore. CommentsTitle: Controller itself is great- condition wasn’t as advertised (sticky buttons on “like new controller)

CommentsTitle: Controller will not hold a charge !  Only works when plugged into a power source.

CommentsContent: When I received my Controller it came in the original box but the main box seals had already been opened. CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 14, 2020
CommentsContent: I cannot recommend this controller.TLDR: I love the paddles, I love the weight, I love the D-pad, and I love the overall customization. However the button contacts are unreliable and often do not register with quick light presses. I think the overall construction of these controllers is mediocre at best, I had one of the trigger sensitivity switches fall off despite the fact I do not use them. A great idea poorly executed, certainly not worth the price tagAfter about a month of owning it, I noticed the "A" button did not fully make contact. If I pressed it with the outside of my thumb, the button press would not register. Not a huge deal but I did order a replacement just to be sure.My replacement had the same issue. I decided to map one of the paddles to "A" instead.About 6 months in the RB button became unresponsive. Using the Xbox accessories app I could see that the button press would disengage depending on how much force I pressed the button (the LB would stay engaged no matter how little force). Having passed my return date I opened the controller up and tried to fix it myself. Any fix I implemented only lasted a few days.The final straw was today the soft plastic cover of one of the trigger switches fell off and now I have just a sharp switch on the back of my controller. It doesn't look to have broken, and it slips back on, so I figure the adhesive wore off. I haven't even had this controller a year.I work in IT, I handle my tech with care, so I haven't chucked it across the room or anything. This Elite controller has been a saga of disappointment. I really like a lot of the features it offers, but it's a heavy gamble that the entire controller will work for an "extended" time. And for the price of almost 3x a standard controller? It's just not worth it

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 16, 2020

CommentsTitle: Huge problem out of the box.

CommentsContent: I just opened my controller, and out of the box, the A button does not respond properly. Everything else, however, is absolutely perfect.
